componenttextpreview: Oh, I don't think we have any specific area. We'd be open to just about anything.
componenttext: Oh, I don't think we have any specific area. We'd be open to just about anything.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Mike Hamilton with Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Mike Hamilton with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We'd like your thoughts on Europe. Obviously, you've got a relatively new management team that's done a nice job and just want to know how they're addressing the weakness. If we x out meat, cheese, how much of your sense of what's going on is customer de-
componenttext: We'd like your thoughts on Europe. Obviously, you've got a relatively new management team that's done a nice job and just want to know how they're addressing the weakness. If we x out meat, cheese, how much of your sense of what's going on is customer de-stocking? How much of it's market weakness if that's definable? And how much of it is their willingness to lose commodity share in a tough environment?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: In Western Europe, it's a small segment, a small, sound, reasonable segment -- a small segment of our Flexible Packaging business. And our management team over there is concentrating on the specialty products, the value-added products where they can offer
componenttext: In Western Europe, it's a small segment, a small, sound, reasonable segment -- a small segment of our Flexible Packaging business. And our management team over there is concentrating on the specialty products, the value-added products where they can offer solutions for our customers and in the end, the consumer, such things as easy-open, such things as re-sealable product lines. And that's what they're concentrating on. And we are a distant, I don't know if we're number two, but we're distant to Amcor Alcan proposition. So we're trying to grow in those niche areas where we can add value.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Is the feeling de-stocking there or some willingness to lose market share off of the commodity portion?
componenttext: Is the feeling de-stocking there or some willingness to lose market share off of the commodity portion?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We're going to run our businesses to return an operating profit and an EPS number for our shareholders. And if those businesses get so competitive that we can't seem to do that, then we'll move on.
componenttext: We're going to run our businesses to return an operating profit and an EPS number for our shareholders. And if those businesses get so competitive that we can't seem to do that, then we'll move on.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: R&D is kind of second quarter what we see, what we get, or will there be some cost reduction out of the integration?
componenttext: R&D is kind of second quarter what we see, what we get, or will there be some cost reduction out of the integration?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It's probably a good proxy for the run rate that we'll have, at least going forward, where we were up $2.2 million second quarter 2010 over 2009. And I would emphasize what Henry mentioned about our Bemis innovation center, which is a very important corne
componenttext: It's probably a good proxy for the run rate that we'll have, at least going forward, where we were up $2.2 million second quarter 2010 over 2009. And I would emphasize what Henry mentioned about our Bemis innovation center, which is a very important cornerstone of our growth strategy to offer our Flexible Packaging customers, differentiable, value-added products. And that comes from our now-enhanced R&D group.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Tim Thein with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Tim Thein with Citigroup.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually David Rose for Tim. I had a question about your capital expenditure guidance. The last couple of years the spending's obviously been a lot more, and you mentioned that you eventually expect it to tick back up to match depreciation. How long
componenttext: It's actually David Rose for Tim. I had a question about your capital expenditure guidance. The last couple of years the spending's obviously been a lot more, and you mentioned that you eventually expect it to tick back up to match depreciation. How long a glide path do you think it will take before depreciation and CapEx come together? And given that you've spent combined, I guess, well over $200 million, is the lower level in the future, will that be enough to get all the spending that your plants need?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Over the last -- this will be the third year in a row that we've had CapEx spending substantially below D&A in our Bemis units. And previous to that, we had saw some opportunities to add technology and to add capacity where needed, which we did. We filled
componenttext: Over the last -- this will be the third year in a row that we've had CapEx spending substantially below D&A in our Bemis units. And previous to that, we had saw some opportunities to add technology and to add capacity where needed, which we did. We filled up a lot of that capacity. We've been very good in our World Class Manufacturing in driving productivity, reducing waste, getting substantially more output out of the equipment we have. With the acquisition of Alcan, we're finding that they have -- also have assets, which are similar to ours, and as you start to focus these, all the assets throughout the new Bemis, and we improved the productivity, we focused those assets. We get more off of those assets, so I think we can have a couple years here of reduced CapEx spending below D&A. Now if FreshCase and a few other things we have in our R&D repertoire breakout, we'll be very happy to increase that spending for those new products.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, first question I had, with your customer base in food and generally, consumer products, are you seeing an improvement, a continuing improvement in their willingness to launch new products, say, relative to what you have seen, Henry, a year ago? A
componenttext: I guess, first question I had, with your customer base in food and generally, consumer products, are you seeing an improvement, a continuing improvement in their willingness to launch new products, say, relative to what you have seen, Henry, a year ago? And how do you expect that to play out within your mix in products the next couple quarters and into 2011?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think our customers see packaging as a way to differentiate themselves in the marketplace. And I really don't believe that in a recession, like we went through here or year-to-year, you see a big change in our customers' willingness to introduce new pac
componenttext: I think our customers see packaging as a way to differentiate themselves in the marketplace. And I really don't believe that in a recession, like we went through here or year-to-year, you see a big change in our customers' willingness to introduce new packages and new products and new formats. So I don't see it because the package is so important in selling the product and whether a consumer picks product A or product B, so I think they'll keep continuing to have come out with new products. We saw all the things we mentioned, some of them with stick packs. We saw some of them in the coffee retail market. Everybody likes the convenience. They like the quality. And I just don't see a new product introduction slowing down.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Would that argue then that your margin should more or less, if we could extract Alcan from the discussion for a minute, which I know is difficult to do, but if you were looking out on a same-store basis, if you will, would that suggest that margins more o
componenttext: Would that argue then that your margin should more or less, if we could extract Alcan from the discussion for a minute, which I know is difficult to do, but if you were looking out on a same-store basis, if you will, would that suggest that margins more or less have reached the level we should expect for the future, i.e. new products are more or less churning at the same level? Or do you think that over time as you bring out new products in line with what your customers have been projecting, that you have a chance to continue to see a margining up of the Flexible business?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We intend to see a margining up of the Flexible business. And I think it's going to be hard to really pick out which ones come from new products or which comes from uplifting the acquisition sales and the acquisition margins that we acquired here.
componenttext: We intend to see a margining up of the Flexible business. And I think it's going to be hard to really pick out which ones come from new products or which comes from uplifting the acquisition sales and the acquisition margins that we acquired here.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take a follow-up question from Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take a follow-up question from Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Henry, I wondered if you could talk a little bit about the Mexican business. I know it's not a big business, but it seems like it has struggled here for the last several years and wondered if you have kind of a sense of when you can really get that busine
componenttext: Henry, I wondered if you could talk a little bit about the Mexican business. I know it's not a big business, but it seems like it has struggled here for the last several years and wondered if you have kind of a sense of when you can really get that business turned around and running at an optimal level.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're going to start to see improvements in our Mexican business in the fourth quarter and through 2011. That's when I think we're going to start to see the improvements. It'll probably take us into 2012 to really get it running right. We bo
componenttext: Well, I think we're going to start to see improvements in our Mexican business in the fourth quarter and through 2011. That's when I think we're going to start to see the improvements. It'll probably take us into 2012 to really get it running right. We bought a small Mexican business a number of years ago, which just kind of got us in the market. The acquisition of Mexico -- or the acquisition of Food Americas Alcan gave a substantial increase in footprint and in assets that we have in Mexico. It is performing poorer than we thought it would be when we made the acquisition, but our management teams have dug in. We've made some changes in the management staff. We've made some changes in our product mix. And I think we're going to start to see some of those benefits flowing through the fourth quarter of this year.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just -- one more time on the resin. Given the drop that we had in the second quarter, it just sounds like we're not going to see much -- you're not assuming much benefit in the third quarter. And it's not like it's going to lag into the fourth q
componenttext: Could you just -- one more time on the resin. Given the drop that we had in the second quarter, it just sounds like we're not going to see much -- you're not assuming much benefit in the third quarter. And it's not like it's going to lag into the fourth quarter, that we're just really not going to see a whole lot of benefit from that. Can you explain why that is the case?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, our resin buy is about half specialty resins and about half polyethylene or commodity-grade resins. The specialty resins, things like nylon, polyesters, acid copolymers went up in price. They stayed at those levels. They're not increasing
componenttext: Well, first off, our resin buy is about half specialty resins and about half polyethylene or commodity-grade resins. The specialty resins, things like nylon, polyesters, acid copolymers went up in price. They stayed at those levels. They're not increasing, but they didn't drop. So to begin with, you have half of slightly more than half of your raw materials for the Bemis Company not changing in the second half of the year. So you're really down to some commodity resins. And the timing of when those fell versus the timing of when we passed those through to our customers, were almost on top of each other. So we're not going to see a large lag because of the timing of when that occurred.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Al Kabili with Macquarie Investments.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Al Kabili with Macquarie Investments.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on cost synergies and relative to the $30 million that you're expecting this year. Can you give an update of how you're tracking towards that $30 million this year, how much you've realized thus far? And then as you look out to
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on cost synergies and relative to the $30 million that you're expecting this year. Can you give an update of how you're tracking towards that $30 million this year, how much you've realized thus far? And then as you look out to next year, and you spent more time with the acquisition, are you feeling more confident on the $60 million annual run rate goal? Is there upside to that?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Al, in terms of this year's synergy performance, we have realized, we're taking action on the SG&A opportunities and plans that we had set out to do right out of the box. And so we are on pace right now to achieve the SG&A cost savings for year one.
componenttext: Sure. Al, in terms of this year's synergy performance, we have realized, we're taking action on the SG&A opportunities and plans that we had set out to do right out of the box. And so we are on pace right now to achieve the SG&A cost savings for year one. We are just starting to see the second component of our year one cost-saving plan, which is raw material advantages. And so we expect those will start to layer in more in Q3 and Q4 so that by the end of 2010, we will have realized that $30 million cost-saving synergy number that we had set out to achieve. In terms of 2011, we still feel very good about the plans that we have in place to extract cost savings as we turn our attention to our plant network. And I think our views about the dollar impact of that have not changed, which is that between the year-end 2010 where we will have realized about $30 million in cost saving synergies and 2011 where we'll be on our run rate of about $60 million in cost-saving synergies, it will be a pretty steady progression from that $30 million to $60 million during the course of 2011. It's not perfectly predictable, but our views about that path and the actions that we're taking to achieve those synergies are really the same as they've been for the last couple months.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Take another follow-up question from George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Take another follow-up question from George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you've gotten a couple of questions on resin previous in the call. I guess one question I would have, in past quarters, you have been able to, at least for a period of time, benefit from the rate of change in your input costs rela to -- as
componenttext: It sounds like you've gotten a couple of questions on resin previous in the call. I guess one question I would have, in past quarters, you have been able to, at least for a period of time, benefit from the rate of change in your input costs rela to -- as those costs are translated into selling prices and passed through. Was there something that made that gap narrower in this particular quarter? Or is it just a, if you will, aberrational timing effect that normally wouldn't occur on a going-forward basis?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at what happened with commodity prices, they really continued to rise through about April and then took a real nosedive through the second part of April and into May. And by the end of the second quarter, they'd really come back to almost the
componenttext: If you look at what happened with commodity prices, they really continued to rise through about April and then took a real nosedive through the second part of April and into May. And by the end of the second quarter, they'd really come back to almost the same levels where the commodity resin prices were at the beginning of the year. And so, it's tough to pin down exactly the impact inter-quarter and intra-quarter. But as we look out over the course of the balance of 2010, where we're basically flat from the beginning of the year to midway through the year, our expectations for commodity prices are really more of a stable environment for the next two quarters.

componenttext: Oh, I think we're seeing some very pleasant surprises as our R&D group works with the Food Americas R&D group. And that's one of the reasons when we saw some of the subtleties that they have and the way they approach things and you mirror it with ours, we have substantial growth opportunities coming out of our R&D group in the future. And that's why we're going forward, and we're excited about putting the R&D organizations together in what we call the Bemis Innovation Center and take advantage of those synergies between the development groups.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: One of things we realized after we closed the acquisition, was that there's actually a very robust pipeline of new technology and innovative ideas that was held in the R&D group at Food Americas that really had not yet been commercialized. And so one of t
componenttext: One of things we realized after we closed the acquisition, was that there's actually a very robust pipeline of new technology and innovative ideas that was held in the R&D group at Food Americas that really had not yet been commercialized. And so one of the things we're doing is working on combining that pipeline of R&D ideas and putting together plans to really commercialize what we've got in inventory. The other thing I've noticed that there are -- there's very robust opportunity to transfer ideas across regions. So it's not just great ideas coming out of North America being exported to South America, but there's a lot of strong technology and product platform in South America that we're going to use to sell into other regions of the world.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Good day, everyone. Welcome to the Bemis Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I will now turn the call over to the Vice President and Treasurer for Bemis Company, Ms. Melanie Miller. Ms. Miller, please go ahead.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Welcome to the Bemis Company Third Quarter 2010 Conference on October 28, 2010. After today's call, a replay will be available on our website, www.bemis.com, under the Investor Relations section.Joining me for this call today are Be
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Welcome to the Bemis Company Third Quarter 2010 Conference on October 28, 2010. After today's call, a replay will be available on our website, www.bemis.com, under the Investor Relations section.
Joining me for this call today are Bemis Company's President and Chief Executive Officer, Henry Theisen; and our Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Scott Ullem. Today, Scott will begin with his comments on the financial results, followed by Henry with comments on the business.
After our comments, we will answer any questions you have. However, in order to allow everyone an opportunity to participate, we ask that you limit yourself to one question at a time with a related follow-up, and then follow back into the queue for any additional question.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind everyone that statements regarding future performance of the company made in this teleconference are forward-looking and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from historical, expected or projected results due to a variety of factors, including currency fluctuations, changes in raw material cost and availability, industry competition, unexpected consumer buying trends or customer order patterns, our ability to pass along increased costs in our selling prices, costs and integration risks associated with business combinations, interest rate fluctuations and regional economic conditions. A more complete list of risk factors is included in our regular SEC filings, including the most recently filed Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009.
Now I'll turn the call over to Scott Ullem.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melanie, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with the results of the third quarter and the growth that we are experiencing in sales and on the bottom line. We reported earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.56 on a GAAP basis a
componenttext:
Thanks, Melanie, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with the results of the third quarter and the growth that we are experiencing in sales and on the bottom line. We reported earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.56 on a GAAP basis and $0.57 excluding special charges associated with acquisition integration.
This is an increase of about 19% over last year's adjusted earnings per share, and it is within our third quarter guidance range of $0.55 to $0.60 that we provided in July.  My comments this morning will focus on the primary drivers impacting operating profit. I will also provide some color on corporate expenses, cash flow and our focus on improving returns on capital.
Net sales this quarter increased by 44%, including the impact of our Food Americas acquisition on March 1 of this year. To get a better measure of organic growth in the top line, we compared actual sales in the third quarter of 2010 to pro forma sales in the third quarter of 2009. With that comparison, sales increased by about 8% from the depressed sales levels of last year. We estimate that this increase was driven equally by volume improvement and increased price mix.
Currency change translations had no net effect on our sales this quarter. Relative to the U.S. dollar, the weaker euro and pound sterling was offset by the stronger Brazilian real and Mexican peso. Selling prices were generally higher across the board, reflecting the raw material cost increases that we experienced during the first half of 2010.  Volumes were also up in certain flexible packaging categories such as dairy and liquids, dry foods, confectionery and snack, beverage overwrap, health and hygiene, industrial and medical and pharmaceutical. In the Pressure Sensitive Materials segment, which represented about 11% of sales this quarter, we enjoyed a volume recovery in the label category and low to mid-single-digit growth in our higher value-added graphic and technical products.
Sales mix was generally consistent from 2009 to 2010. Last year, we benefited from sales mix improvements during the third quarter, driven by increased sales of higher value-added products that delivered increased margins to the operating profit line as well.  In 2010, we have maintained this sales mix while experiencing volume growth across the majority of our product offerings. Volumes in our European operations continue to be negatively impacted by weak market conditions in that region.
In addition to top line improvements, operating profit is being impacted by several other factors in 2010. First, the lower operating profit margins associated with the newly acquired Food Americas business that have reduced our overall operating margins in 2010. Second, we are on track to record $30 million of cost savings synergies related primarily to SG&A and raw material purchasing synergies. We continue to expect these savings to grow to a run rate of approximately $60 million by the end of 2011.
In addition, our World Class Manufacturing initiatives continue to make important improvements in our cost structure around the world. The discipline that is part of that program ensures that improvements are made and maintained and become the basis for further improvement in the future. Using these initiatives, we have improved our operational efficiency, reduced waste and manufacturing cost and reduced our capital expenditure needs. Over the next few years, we expect these factors to contribute to improved operating profit.
SG&A and R&D costs have increased to reflect the impact of the Food Americas acquisition in 2010. As a percentage of sales, our SG&A rate is decreased by 2% to 8.8% of sales in 2010. R&D, as a percentage of sales, has increased slightly. In both cases, the current run rate is a reasonable proxy for these costs as a percentage of sales going forward.
In the third quarter of 2009, other operating income and expense included $16 million of transaction-related fees. In the third quarter of 2010, we recorded about $1.2 million of such fees. The remaining balances of other operating income and expense included exchange gains and losses and the fiscal incentive income that we earned in Brazil.
Other non-operating income in 2009 reflected the gain on the sale of a building in Brazil and interest income from the investment of the proceeds of the acquisition pre-funding of July 2009. In 2010, other non-operating expense, primarily reflects hedging cost associated with an intercompany loan to our Brazilian subsidiary.
Our tax rate for the third quarter was 36% and we expect this rate to continue through the fourth quarter. We recorded an $833,000 loss in the discontinued operations during the third quarter. These operations were sold during the third quarter on July 13 for $75 million net cash proceeds after selling costs.
We continue to fulfill an obligation to provide the buyer with product to support certain manufacturing needs. Those sales were considered discontinued operations until the sale was completed. Now those sales are included in continuing operations, and the value of these sales currently is approximately $15 million per quarter.
Looking at the fourth financial schedule in the press release titled Operating Profit and Pretax Profit, you'll see a line titled General Corporate Expenses. This line is an accumulation of the cost in pretax profit that are related to general corporate functions. The corporate expenses in the third quarter of 2009 reflect the usually high amount of transaction-related fees incurred. For both the second and third quarters of 2010, we have reported corporate expenses in the $25 million range, and we expect this to be a reasonable run rate for the next year.
Turning to the cash flow statement. It is important to note, cash flow in 2009 benefited substantially from a reduction in working capital, primarily related to a sharp decline in raw material costs. In 2010, raw material costs are somewhat higher, and volume growth in several product categories has caused additional growth in working capital through the summer. As a result, we now expect working capital to be a use of cash for the full year. However, we expect some improvement during the fourth quarter, which is a seasonally stronger quarter for cash flow.
Since we closed the Food Americas acquisition on March 1, we have reduced outstanding debt by $130 million. In addition, we spent $29 million buying back 1 million shares of Bemis common stock. Going forward, we will use a disciplined approach to allocating cash between capital expenditures, acquisitions, debt reduction and share repurchase. Our goal is to generate superior total returns for our shareholders through dividends, payback on internal growth initiatives, acquisitions and the strategic use of our balance sheet.
I'd like to spend a moment on capital expenditures. Through the third quarter, we spent $65 million on CapEx. We now expect our total CapEx for 2010 to approximate $115 million. This is lower than our previous guidance of approximately $140 million and our original guidance in March in the range of $160 million to $170 million, and there are several reasons for this improvement. 
One, we have been very pleased with the assets we acquired with Food Americas. Generally speaking, the net 20 plants that we have added to our plant network are well maintained and modern. But more importantly, we are now able to streamline operations and run our products where they are most productive. This focus on where we run our products and specification management has increased the overall effective capacity of our operations.
Two, our World Class Manufacturing initiatives are providing us better leverage of our existing assets. And three, some of this year's capital projects have been pushed to 2011 simply because projects don't neatly fall into calendar year reporting periods. We still expect CapEx to lag our expected depreciation and amortization levels of about $210 million for this perceivable future.
Looking ahead, our total year 2010 guidance is $2.10 dollars to $2.15 per share, which is a 12% to 16% improvement over our record 2009 performance of $1.86 per share. This 2010 guidance reflects guidance of $0.48 to $0.53 for the fourth quarter.
We are pleased with the first 10 months of our expanded global operations, and we look forward to continuing stronger performance in the balance of this year and next.
Now I'll turn it over to Henry for his comments.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Today, I will focus my comments on three main topics, the Food Americas integration, the current business environment, and the 2010 climate for raw materials. The Food Americas acquisition is now seven months old, and we are making gre
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Today, I will focus my comments on three main topics, the Food Americas integration, the current business environment, and the 2010 climate for raw materials. 
The Food Americas acquisition is now seven months old, and we are making great progress with our integration. Our customers have reacted positively to the combined operations, and are focused on achieving a seamless integration, resulting in high-quality customer service and enhanced product innovation. Our ability to consistently deliver quality product to customer's facilities throughout integration process has solidified our position as a reliable packaging supplier.
During the third quarter, our organic sales growth was supported by volume growth in areas where our unique materials offer customers high-performance solutions to suit their packaging needs. This included those higher growth categories that benefit from demand for preparation meals and single-serve beverages, as well as condiments and hard-to-hold sauces. Examples of quick preparation meals would be steam-able frozen vegetables, where the vegetables our microwave in a package that has encorporated features that allow the steam to build up, to cook the product and then the package softens and has an easy open future.  Lunch kits, which include individual package components like bread, meat, cheese and condiments, that consumers use to make a deli-style sandwich, shelf-stable microwavable meals would read to our packaging, and frozen meal kits that include pre-cooked rice or pasta, vegetables and a meat.  In addition, sales volume in categories that had weakened in 2009 have rebounded a bit this quarter. These include sales of packaging into categories for beverage wraps, confectionery, frozen foods and industrial products. 
In Latin America, our Mexico operations performed better this quarter. We are pleased with the quick response by our management team to streamline specifications and effectively schedule facilities to improve profitability in that region. Our Brazilian operations are performing well, overcoming the competitive disadvantage of the recent strength of the local currency. We continue to see this region as critically important to our international growth strategy. Brazil is experiencing strong economic growth compared to the rest of the world, and the anticipated emergence of stronger consumer demand for protein and healthcare products will create future volume growth and sales mix improvement, opportunities using our most sophisticated product lines.
As we stated in our July conference call, our European operations have been experiencing a difficult environment in 2010, which put pressure on sales volumes and made it challenging to recover the increasing cost of raw materials. Raw material costs have taken an interesting course in 2010. Cost increased during the first quarter of the year, and while specialty resin cost plateaued, commodity resin cost begun to come down again in the latter half of the second quarter. During the third quarter, raw material costs begun to increase once again, but in addition, competition for capacity has created a shortage of oriented polyester film in the market.  Bemis is well supplied and is meeting all of our customers needs. We do not anticipate any production issues as a result of the shortage. However, it has already caused polyester resin and oriented-film prices to increase in the fourth quarter.
I am pleased that our supply chain management group has been able to secure and maintain a sufficient supply of oriented-polyester film to meet the needs of our customers. I am especially pleased with the programs they have put in place to ensure we have a secure supply of it in the future. These increasing raw material costs will put modest pressure on operating margins during the fourth quarter, while our disciplined business model adjust selling prices to accommodate those increases.
Going forward, we will continue to invest in platforms that support those markets and product lines that value our technology. In the areas where the competitive landscape is more aggressive, our world class manufacturing efforts will continuously improve efficiency and control cost and allow us to compete, grow and improve profitably. 
Now I'd like to open up the call for questions.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Could you give us a bit more detail on the lower CapEx guidance? I'm just wondering about the reduction in the project shift. And then to follow up on that, could you give us, I guess, an update on the synergies? And It sounds like with the reduced CapEx and how modern and streamlined these facilities are and your pressure with how the integration is tracking, but the synergies could possibly get accelerated a bit or you might be fighting a bit more?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, as far as the CapEx spending, we are generating additional capacity by taking a look at where we place our products and what specifications we run. If you look at some of the things that Alcan was really good at was like for instance, foi
componenttext: Well, first off, as far as the CapEx spending, we are generating additional capacity by taking a look at where we place our products and what specifications we run. If you look at some of the things that Alcan was really good at was like for instance, foil laminations, so we can consolidate foiled laminations in certain facilities. We can take a look at where Alcan, for instance, made packaging for processed meats, and we may process meat packaging films, which specifications run best on which equipment and then which plant. So what we're doing is we're generating a lot of capacity by really taking a good look at what our manufacturing footprint is and placing the products that fit best on that footprint in the appropriate place. And we're generating quite a bit of additional capacity to grow our business in almost all the areas. As far as synergies, we're very happy with the synergies. I think we can continue to grow synergies, and I'm very happy. I look forward to $60 million that we promised through 2011 as a run rate.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that, Sara. On synergies, we're right on track with where we thought we would maybe. In 2010, our focus has been on reducing SG&A, and we made early progress on that, and got after a lot of those SG&A cost reductions even in the first
componenttext: I would just add to that, Sara. On synergies, we're right on track with where we thought we would maybe. In 2010, our focus has been on reducing SG&A, and we made early progress on that, and got after a lot of those SG&A cost reductions even in the first month after we closed on March 1. And the secondary focus for this year has been in raw material cost savings, resulting from the combination of the two businesses. Next year, what's really going to drive us from the $30 million that we'll book in 2010 to a run rate of about $60 million by the end of 2011 is a lot of the plant consolidation cost savings that we have planned and are expecting to get next year.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So plant consolidation, does that mean putting products in different places or are you closing plants?
componenttext: So plant consolidation, does that mean putting products in different places or are you closing plants?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not closing plant. It's optimizing our plant network. We've said all along that is not a capacity reduction, acquisition, rather, we're pleased with the additional capacity we picked up. This is merely, as Henry said, optimizing the way we run our busines
componenttext: Not closing plant. It's optimizing our plant network. We've said all along that is not a capacity reduction, acquisition, rather, we're pleased with the additional capacity we picked up. This is merely, as Henry said, optimizing the way we run our business across the production capacity around our system, now which includes over 80 production facilities around the world.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: We'll go next to Panjabi Ghansham (sic)[Ghansham Panjabi] [Robert W. Baird].

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Curious on whether, is there a strategic need here in Europe, strategic on requirements from your customers to be in Europe in terms of your footprint there? Because it seems like you lack critical mass in there, and it's the time to start considering str
componenttext: Curious on whether, is there a strategic need here in Europe, strategic on requirements from your customers to be in Europe in terms of your footprint there? Because it seems like you lack critical mass in there, and it's the time to start considering strategic options for this business.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think it's strategic from our customer base that we have facilities in Europe. We picked up most of those facilities through acquisition. And we bought the Shrink Bag business and there was a plant in Europe we acquired as we went through the
componenttext: Yes, I don't think it's strategic from our customer base that we have facilities in Europe. We picked up most of those facilities through acquisition. And we bought the Shrink Bag business and there was a plant in Europe we acquired as we went through the pressure-sensitive business, we acquired a facility in Valkeakoski, Finland. We acquired a facility from our Clysar operations, but it is long term, a good market for us. We believe long term, those technologies and the products that we make will have a fit in there. I do have to admit that we are by far, very distant to Amcor now. But if you look at our business, the areas that we've invested in are the ones that we put technology in, those are holding up well. They just don't have enough volume yet to offset what we acquired through the acquisition three.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then also, could you update us on what trends you're seeing in resin by geography, so in North America, Western Europe and also on Brazil as well?
componenttext: And then also, could you update us on what trends you're seeing in resin by geography, so in North America, Western Europe and also on Brazil as well?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're seeing rising raw material cost in all the regions. It seems a little stronger in Europe, but it's really rising pretty comparatively in all three of those key regions.
componenttext: We're seeing rising raw material cost in all the regions. It seems a little stronger in Europe, but it's really rising pretty comparatively in all three of those key regions.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just piggyback on Ghansham's question regarding Europe, maybe actually one more. Europe, obviously, at least from our vantage point has not been as good of a region, that's perhaps the company might have hoped it was or would be back earlier i
componenttext: I wanted to just piggyback on Ghansham's question regarding Europe, maybe actually one more. Europe, obviously, at least from our vantage point has not been as good of a region, that's perhaps the company might have hoped it was or would be back earlier in the decade. And we realized Bemis has terrific technology. We realize a great opportunity to utilize that technology and leverage it overtime. But is there a time, maybe not next quarter, but over the next couple of years, where you finally make a decision, look, we have enough opportunities in the U.S. in Latin America where we don't have to keep hitting our heads up against the wall in Europe and make a cut date or fish decision.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't see that in the near future. I think we still have an opportunity to enhance our business in Europe. We've made the investments in those technologies, and I think we really will see some improvement. But it's not going to come easy. We have also f
componenttext: I don't see that in the near future. I think we still have an opportunity to enhance our business in Europe. We've made the investments in those technologies, and I think we really will see some improvement. But it's not going to come easy. We have also fall in a time here where the economy of Europe is really hurting us. So I don't know how long can the economy of Europe stay slower. And that improves, we're going to have a good opportunity to grow. We're not looking at trying to make a stake in the European market.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've already seen the company fall back capital spending this year, and you haven't even begun to discuss whereas really begin the optimization of the facilities yet, and that's coming next year. Should we expect that even if there's some pushing out int
componenttext: We've already seen the company fall back capital spending this year, and you haven't even begun to discuss whereas really begin the optimization of the facilities yet, and that's coming next year. Should we expect that even if there's some pushing out into 2011 of capital projects that should have hit this year that you can more or less maintain this level of capital spending for the next couple of years?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We will likely spend more in CapEx in 2011 than we will in 2010. But we expect that for some period of time to come, multiple years, we will be investing less in CapEx than our book depreciation amortization, which we think it will be about $210 million i
componenttext: We will likely spend more in CapEx in 2011 than we will in 2010. But we expect that for some period of time to come, multiple years, we will be investing less in CapEx than our book depreciation amortization, which we think it will be about $210 million in 2010.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to the line of Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to the line of Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just curious, Scott, given everything you've said about the acquisition of Food Americas, why that synergy target isn't becoming larger?
componenttext: Just curious, Scott, given everything you've said about the acquisition of Food Americas, why that synergy target isn't becoming larger?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, keep in mind, these are identified cost savings. And they were developed after a lot of work or through a lot of work during a time that we were negotiating the acquisition with Food Americas and the lengthy period of time between signing a definiti
componenttext: Well, keep in mind, these are identified cost savings. And they were developed after a lot of work or through a lot of work during a time that we were negotiating the acquisition with Food Americas and the lengthy period of time between signing a definitive agreement and closing the deal in March 1. And so we have a game plan in place that we have been executing. We expect that over time, the same way we do in our regular operations, we will identify further opportunities to take out cost. But the $30 million this year growing to $60 million run rate by the end of 2011 is based on that specific game plan that we put in place with identified cost savings at that time. Again, it's the same way we're running our business and using World Class Manufacturing initiatives to improve our cost position. We expect that we'll be able to do that with the 20 Food Americas facilities that we acquired as well.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It just sounds like you're probably finding a few more opportunities than you expected. If I could, as a follow-on, Henry, can you just talk a little bit about Asia? I mean, I appreciate the fact that Latin America is a very good market for you and certai
componenttext: It just sounds like you're probably finding a few more opportunities than you expected. If I could, as a follow-on, Henry, can you just talk a little bit about Asia? I mean, I appreciate the fact that Latin America is a very good market for you and certainly a growing market and a market where you've got a nice presence, but we've also got a lot of places in Asia that are growing a very, very rapidly and the population base, frankly is just much, much larger.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have an interest in expanding our foot print in Asia. We do spend time trying to find strategic acquisitions like we were lucky enough to do with t Dixie Toga in South America. We have been investing. We have three key footprints, our medical packaging
componenttext: We have an interest in expanding our foot print in Asia. We do spend time trying to find strategic acquisitions like we were lucky enough to do with t Dixie Toga in South America. We have been investing. We have three key footprints, our medical packaging program in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. We recently have put in a converting operations just outside Shanghai in supporting of our protein markets, Shrink Bag markets and fresh meat packaging as well as our medical device. And we did acquire a fresh meat packaging facility, if you will, in New Zealand. So we're going to build on those three, and we're going to continue to look for an acquisition that can make sense, one that is, but we're not going to rush there and try to do something that's big and dilutive to the company. But we are interested in that region, and we are trying to explore opportunities to grow.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to the line of Philip Ng with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to the line of Philip Ng with Jefferies.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you guys have a good amount of new products and you've seen pretty good traction. But in the past, you guys have had to walk away from some low margin business. I'm just trying to get a handicap all together when I look at 2011. What type o
componenttext: It sounds like you guys have a good amount of new products and you've seen pretty good traction. But in the past, you guys have had to walk away from some low margin business. I'm just trying to get a handicap all together when I look at 2011. What type of organic growth are you expecting?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, we're in the process, Phil, of putting together our planning for 2011. And I think we'll have more comments in what we see is our growth opportunities and how we're going to approach the market as we conclude our planning session here in the ne
componenttext: Right now, we're in the process, Phil, of putting together our planning for 2011. And I think we'll have more comments in what we see is our growth opportunities and how we're going to approach the market as we conclude our planning session here in the next couple of months.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But in the past, I think you said the long-term stable run rate was like low to mid-single-digit run rate, is that still sustainable going forward, you think?
componenttext: But in the past, I think you said the long-term stable run rate was like low to mid-single-digit run rate, is that still sustainable going forward, you think?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if you think about our end markets and the customers that we serve, they are GDP plus a couple of points kind of growth environments. And that is the same profile that we face as it relates to organic growth opportunities. And so that, I think, what
componenttext: Well, if you think about our end markets and the customers that we serve, they are GDP plus a couple of points kind of growth environments. And that is the same profile that we face as it relates to organic growth opportunities. And so that, I think, what you've seen us do historically is probably a good indicator of what we'll be able to do going forward. But I want to note that -- what's important to note is we are investing not just in areas that represent good organic growth, but areas that represent good opportunity to expand margins. So even in markets that maybe growing at low to mid-single digits, we're investing in platforms where we can get nice pickups in our operating profit margins.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to the line of Al Kabili with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll go next to the line of Al Kabili with Macquarie.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could help us and maybe I missed it, clarify how much Europe was down in terms of EBIT year-over-year?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could help us and maybe I missed it, clarify how much Europe was down in terms of EBIT year-over-year?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't usually get in to that sort of detail talking about the specific EBIT margins by region. But clearly. The volumes were down, and total sales were down once again, double-digit year-over-year. They had a pretty good year, even volume wise, in 2009
componenttext: We don't usually get in to that sort of detail talking about the specific EBIT margins by region. But clearly. The volumes were down, and total sales were down once again, double-digit year-over-year. They had a pretty good year, even volume wise, in 2009. The economic conditions really didn't seem to hit our European operations until early 2010. And this has sort of been an ongoing issue for them in 2010, dealing with lower volumes and it's really the lower volumes causing the overhead absorption not to be as good as it was a year ago in addition to higher raw material cost.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess, a follow-up question is, with CapEx coming down and below D&A, at least, for the foreseeable future, I know there's some deleveraging going on as well, but what's the appetite near term for other uses of free cash flow, such as share repurcha
componenttext: And I guess, a follow-up question is, with CapEx coming down and below D&A, at least, for the foreseeable future, I know there's some deleveraging going on as well, but what's the appetite near term for other uses of free cash flow, such as share repurchases or bolt-on M&A acquisitions?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our priorities for cash flow are as follows: first, dividends. We've increased our dividends for the last 27 years. We've paid the dividend since 1922, and you should expect that we're going to continue to pay an increasing dividend over time. Second, we
componenttext: Our priorities for cash flow are as follows: first, dividends. We've increased our dividends for the last 27 years. We've paid the dividend since 1922, and you should expect that we're going to continue to pay an increasing dividend over time. Second, we will continue to invest in internal growth initiatives that represent attractive return on investment opportunities. Third, we are looking actively for acquisition opportunities, but those are unpredictable and not something that we can plan quarter-to-quarter as it relates to use of cash flow. What we then do is look at, and we'll continue to do, is look at using cash to pay down debt. We pay down $130 million in debt since the acquisition and to buy back stock. And as we mentioned, we bought back 1 million shares in the third quarter. We do have an authorization to repurchase an additional 3.1 million shares. And we think very carefully about what we do with every dollar of cash flow that comes in.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to the line of Chip Dillon with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to the line of Chip Dillon with Credit Suisse.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I might have missed this. But as you look at your fourth quarter expectation, which I would imagine were a little bit less than maybe what you were thinking a few months ago, would you say most of the lower, I guess, outlook is tied to volumes in util
componenttext: And I might have missed this. But as you look at your fourth quarter expectation, which I would imagine were a little bit less than maybe what you were thinking a few months ago, would you say most of the lower, I guess, outlook is tied to volumes in utilization? Or is it tied to the raw material pressures and therefore, it's just a matter of time before you pass those on?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the vast majority is related to the raw materials. And as you know, as we've talked before a lot of those sometimes because of the way our contracts are structured, about 2/3 of them have escalators, de-escalators, and can take up to 90 days to pa
componenttext: I think the vast majority is related to the raw materials. And as you know, as we've talked before a lot of those sometimes because of the way our contracts are structured, about 2/3 of them have escalators, de-escalators, and can take up to 90 days to pass those raw materials through. The other third, we take a look at it, we can pass those through immediately on an order-to-order basis. So it takes us 60 to 90 days to pass that through. So I think that's a little bit of headwinds for us here in the fourth quarter.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I also like to clarify that our guidance throughout the year, we've been raising our total year guidance throughout the year. So as we look at -- I don't think the fourth quarter expectations, our guidance for fourth quarter is lower than we had expected
componenttext: I also like to clarify that our guidance throughout the year, we've been raising our total year guidance throughout the year. So as we look at -- I don't think the fourth quarter expectations, our guidance for fourth quarter is lower than we had expected earlier in the year. I think we had hoped in our July estimate, had some range in there for a various activity with raw material cost. And unfortunately, with raw materials cost going up, we're in the lower half of the range we've put out in July. But I think that our range for fourth quarter by itself is really very close to what we've expected for quite a while.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned you will get $30 million, or I think just clarify, are you going to be in the $30 million run rate at the end of this year with synergies or is that what you get for this year? And then if you could just sort of tell us how we would expect t
componenttext: You mentioned you will get $30 million, or I think just clarify, are you going to be in the $30 million run rate at the end of this year with synergies or is that what you get for this year? And then if you could just sort of tell us how we would expect those to phase-in throughout 2011 to get to the $60 million? Is it kind of a straight-line or is it lumpy?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chip. The answer is yes, it's $30 million booked in 2010, which means that the run rate by the end of this year will be higher than $30 million as we go towards that target $60 million run rate by the end of 2011. It's not a perfect straight-line sl
componenttext: Sure, Chip. The answer is yes, it's $30 million booked in 2010, which means that the run rate by the end of this year will be higher than $30 million as we go towards that target $60 million run rate by the end of 2011. It's not a perfect straight-line slope between where we are now and where we will be at the end of 2011. There is some lumpiness to it, but you'll see us gradually grow from where we are now to the $60 million range a year from now.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to line of Sara Magers with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go next to line of Sara Magers with Wells Fargo.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit of about, I guess, price recovery in Q4. Are you expecting, I guess, price cost parity in the quarter? And then to follow up on that, I'm wondering what your assumption is regarding resins for the balance of
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit of about, I guess, price recovery in Q4. Are you expecting, I guess, price cost parity in the quarter? And then to follow up on that, I'm wondering what your assumption is regarding resins for the balance of the year.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have booked into our fourth quarter forecast the price increases in raw materials that we have seen so far. And we're predicting that, that pricing level will continue through the fourth quarter. That's what we've baked into our estimate here.
componenttext: We have booked into our fourth quarter forecast the price increases in raw materials that we have seen so far. And we're predicting that, that pricing level will continue through the fourth quarter. That's what we've baked into our estimate here.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And normally, the way that our business model works after about three months or so, pretty much the majority of our selling prices have been adjusted to be at parity with the raw material costs.
componenttext: And normally, the way that our business model works after about three months or so, pretty much the majority of our selling prices have been adjusted to be at parity with the raw material costs.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just quickly, I'm wondering about how Q4 has been trending so far in terms of demand. From what I understand, I think that -- isn't October typically one of the larger months of the quarter? I'm just wondering what you're seeing so far.
componenttext: And then just quickly, I'm wondering about how Q4 has been trending so far in terms of demand. From what I understand, I think that -- isn't October typically one of the larger months of the quarter? I'm just wondering what you're seeing so far.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The demand that we have going to the fourth quarter is strong. We feel good about it. And you're right, our October is our big month, and then you kind of go up through the holiday seasons, and that's what always makes the fourth quarter a little slower t
componenttext: The demand that we have going to the fourth quarter is strong. We feel good about it. And you're right, our October is our big month, and then you kind of go up through the holiday seasons, and that's what always makes the fourth quarter a little slower than some of the others. But we feel very good with our volume and our backlogs going into the fourth quarter.

componenttext: On a relative basis, this October compares to past October?

componenttext: I think it will be slightly ahead of past Octobers.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to come back to capital spending and cash flow, and these questions. Before, Scott, when I was going through the Q&A with you, I just wanted to ask a follow on. Do you think $140 million is the relevant range for '11 and '12 spending? I know you ha
componenttext: I want to come back to capital spending and cash flow, and these questions. Before, Scott, when I was going through the Q&A with you, I just wanted to ask a follow on. Do you think $140 million is the relevant range for '11 and '12 spending? I know you haven't finalized your '11 budget, or do you think that's too low or too high at this juncture?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're not just far enough along, George, to give you a good indicator for 2011. We will when it come out on February 1 with our full guidance earnings, also talk about CapEx. But we just don't have a more accurate beat on it yet.
componenttext: We're not just far enough along, George, to give you a good indicator for 2011. We will when it come out on February 1 with our full guidance earnings, also talk about CapEx. But we just don't have a more accurate beat on it yet.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of uses of cash, I guess, piggy-backing the earlier question from Al, you enumerated the normal uses of cash. Obviously, the company has had a great dividend track record you've made acquisitions, you want to invest in places where you're get
componenttext: And in terms of uses of cash, I guess, piggy-backing the earlier question from Al, you enumerated the normal uses of cash. Obviously, the company has had a great dividend track record you've made acquisitions, you want to invest in places where you're getting high margins and returns and ultimately, you also buy back stock. As you sit here today relative maybe Bemis' priorities on cash flow s few years ago, do you think anyone of those four or five are more important on a going-forward basis and might have been the case previously?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, we've got a lot more debt now than we did before. Granted, we also have a lot of additional earnings, but we think carefully about managing our debt levels. We're comfortable with where we are today. But we also want to make sure
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, we've got a lot more debt now than we did before. Granted, we also have a lot of additional earnings, but we think carefully about managing our debt levels. We're comfortable with where we are today. But we also want to make sure we preserve flexibility for acquisitions that we expect will come. But it's critically important that we think carefully about every dollar that comes in the house, and whether we apply that to debt paydown. And right now, we do not have any maturities that are coming quickly. The next bond that matures is in the spring of 2012. And as we've said multiple times, we are not just going to sit on cash. And so that's the reason why we'll look towards our share repurchases in the public market versus paying down commercial paper. And at the same time, preserving the flexibility that we need to make acquisitions.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Chris Manuel, KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Chris Manuel, KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you. The first is on Brazil. With all of the -- we're hearing quite a bit of chatter out of folks down there that the packaging mix is evolving and changing so, so quickly. And with all of your -- to more towards flexible packaging and t
componenttext: Two questions for you. The first is on Brazil. With all of the -- we're hearing quite a bit of chatter out of folks down there that the packaging mix is evolving and changing so, so quickly. And with all of your -- to more towards flexible packaging and things of that nature, with your thinking, tell us the business down there that -- is there an opportunity or maybe you could talk about what the opportunities over the next couple of years for that business to have 10%, 15%, 20% of volume levels to capture a lot of these conversion? So I guess the question is, could you give us a little color on what's happening in Brazil and maybe where volume levels are now?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brazil is in an exciting part of our growth strategy, going forward. We were lucky enough to acquire Dixie Toga, which is the number one flexible packaging company in Latin America. We're well positioned. It's been a strategy all along to have that kind o
componenttext: Brazil is in an exciting part of our growth strategy, going forward. We were lucky enough to acquire Dixie Toga, which is the number one flexible packaging company in Latin America. We're well positioned. It's been a strategy all along to have that kind of a base to work from. We always felt that as the population becomes more middle-class, that they're going to want the things that we all have here. Food safety, medical sterility are all important. We have invested in the Shrink Bag business. We've invested in putting assets into Brazil that can grow in those key market areas. And we look forward to some very good growth, not just in some of the more older established Dixie Toga product lines, but also with our pharmaceutical business that we gained through the acquisition of Alcan, through the technologies that we could put into it in the packaging of protein. Also the success, all the convenience features that we have. And we look to grow our Medical Device business down there also. So we look for some exciting growth in Brazil, especially in those key areas that we like to invest in.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up question had to do with your sensitive business. And I apologize because I jumped on the call a little late if you already talked about this. But the trajectory, as we've gone through the year, has moved down a bit, as you look at th
componenttext: And then my follow-up question had to do with your sensitive business. And I apologize because I jumped on the call a little late if you already talked about this. But the trajectory, as we've gone through the year, has moved down a bit, as you look at the EBIT contribution quarter-by-quarter. Is there anything unusual happening there that is driving that, or should we rebound back to the upper single digit level on a go-forward basis?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it should rebound back to the upper single digits on a go-forward basis. We've had good growth this year compared to last year in our Pressure Sensitive business. We have had some cost pressures in Pressure Sensitive in raw materials that we're wo
componenttext: I think it should rebound back to the upper single digits on a go-forward basis. We've had good growth this year compared to last year in our Pressure Sensitive business. We have had some cost pressures in Pressure Sensitive in raw materials that we're working hard to pass through right now, much like we have in the flexible packaging area.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Margins in that business are also very impacted by sales mix, which could vary from one quarter to the other. And I would say, second quarter is generally a pretty strong margin quarter for Pressure Sensitive, because of the strength of the sales in graph
componenttext: Margins in that business are also very impacted by sales mix, which could vary from one quarter to the other. And I would say, second quarter is generally a pretty strong margin quarter for Pressure Sensitive, because of the strength of the sales in graphic and technical product in that particular part of the year.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to the from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: On Pressure Sensitive, we've heard from several trade contacts recently that you have also gone with the market with some pricing increases. If you mentioned it already on the call, I apologize I didn't hear it. But could you comment on that, if that is correct, in fact?

componenttext: We don't normally talk about those particular events on a conference call or in press releases. We do have very strong discipline throughout Bemis Company's Flexible and Pressure Sensitive to the extent that we have raw material cost increases, we directly increased selling prices as soon as possible in areas where we can't competitively. So I think hopefully, that addresses your question. We've had raw material cost increase in chemical throughout both of our business segments over the last couple of months. So perhaps, that's what you're referring to.

componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on resin. And normally, resin peaked in North America around the spring and then fell. And then, normally, you would have benefited from the lag on the way down as well. And it just doesn't seem like this time around, you've seen that temporary lag benefit. And I'm wondering if you could just help us with what's happened there, things on the specialty resins that's overwhelming that if you could just help us think about that.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Before I let Henry talk a little bit resin cost, in the second quarter, you're right that, that's the trajectory that resin cost were going. There were increasing in the first quarter and then started to decrease in May. But those were really -- the decre
componenttext: Before I let Henry talk a little bit resin cost, in the second quarter, you're right that, that's the trajectory that resin cost were going. There were increasing in the first quarter and then started to decrease in May. But those were really -- the decreases were coming primarily in the commodity resins. And because they started decreasing half way through the second quarter, some of that benefit would've been received in the second quarter. So really muted the impact of the higher raw material cost going into the second quarter, and then the benefit that you normally would have expected in the third quarter, it really only benefited the first parts of the third quarter, I would say, on the commodity side.
