headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Dave Rose, on for Tim Thein. I'm not sure if you've talked about this before, but the Alcan acquisition from what I understand, we didn't get a good look as to what sort of pensions you had to take over as part of that. So I'm wondering if you cou
componenttext: This is Dave Rose, on for Tim Thein. I'm not sure if you've talked about this before, but the Alcan acquisition from what I understand, we didn't get a good look as to what sort of pensions you had to take over as part of that. So I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about where you expect counting contributions and/or expense to go maybe not in the fourth quarter, but in 2011 and how you think that will impact your cash flow going forward?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I can address that. In the Alcan acquisition, we actually negotiated an asset purchase for the majority of the acquisition. And so there were no additional pension or post retiree medical liabilities that we took on with that. All of those employees
componenttext: Sure. I can address that. In the Alcan acquisition, we actually negotiated an asset purchase for the majority of the acquisition. And so there were no additional pension or post retiree medical liabilities that we took on with that. All of those employees of Alcan came into Bemis Company as new employees of Bemis into our current benefit plan. As far as pension contributions going forward, we had in the first quarter of this year a small $15 million pension contribution. It's our focus to maintain roughly 100% funded status in both of our pension plan, and that helped us get there for 2010. Going into 2011, again, I would anticipate at this point, there's no required contribution, but depending on what the discount rate is at the end of the year and what the funding status ends up that we may decide, given our cash flow projections to put some small amount into the pension plan in 2011. But again, no required contributions. And pension expense grew from 2009 to 2010. Given what the discount rates are looking right now, I would anticipate that it's appropriate estimate and increased again for 2011. But we don't really know until we get to December 31 and see where the discount rates end up. So at this point, at least, I would expect the pension expense to be about the same as where we are in 2010, which is roughly, I think, $20 million to $25 million, and likely a little bit higher than that.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow on with regards to deferred taxes, I know that it was part of the acquisition purchase price. How are those going to flow into cash over time? I know for the first couple of quarter that you've owned Alcan, that's been fairly flat wit
componenttext: And then as a follow on with regards to deferred taxes, I know that it was part of the acquisition purchase price. How are those going to flow into cash over time? I know for the first couple of quarter that you've owned Alcan, that's been fairly flat within cash flow. Is that the line item that you should expect to see increase next year?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the deferred tax, the cash flows of deferred taxes or the cash flows of the tax benefit that we received in the Alcan acquisition because of the fact that we structured it as an asset purchase, those cash benefit, the net present value over
componenttext: With regard to the deferred tax, the cash flows of deferred taxes or the cash flows of the tax benefit that we received in the Alcan acquisition because of the fact that we structured it as an asset purchase, those cash benefit, the net present value over this is about $80 million to $100 million. And that's expected to roll into cash flow over the life of those assets. And as you look at that, the best way to model that is probably to say if you divide it evenly over seven years, you won't be too far off in any one year. Obviously, there's some that would go for substantially longer than that. But really, the bulk of it will be received over the next seven years, but not a dramatic cash flow improvement in any one-year, but we will get it in the near term.

And that was could you talk a little bit about what the volume trajectory has been like the last couple of quarters? I know we talked about a lot of opportunity. But do you think that over the next two, three, four years, there's as an opportunity for that to be, given ahead of all the conversion coming, there are double-digit type volume environment for you down in Brazil?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start by saying what 2010 volumes have been like and if you think about Brazil, remember, their winter is in North America, summer and vice versa. What we saw was really strong volume double-digit nice volume growth in Brazil year-over-year in the
componenttext: Let me start by saying what 2010 volumes have been like and if you think about Brazil, remember, their winter is in North America, summer and vice versa. What we saw was really strong volume double-digit nice volume growth in Brazil year-over-year in the first half of 2010. And now in the third quarter, volume was not as big a driver, not as strong as it was before. But it's also the latter part of winter in the third quarter in Brazil. So it's not the strongest time for their products. They're coming in now to their strong summer season, as we enter into our fourth quarter and first quarter. The Huhtamaki acquisition we made last year really focused on a lot of ice cream packaging, which is obviously a big summertime product. And they have a lot of powdered drink mix and things like that. So in any event, I think while the third quarter was slower year-over-year volume improvement, we have seen some really strong volume improvement year-to-date in 2010. And would expect that to continue, going forward over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: I would expect that as Melanie described it, good double-digit growth in those quarters and then slow down. The next trend that she's talking about in 2010 should continue into 2011 and 2012 for us.

componenttext: Well, we serve other countries in South America through our production facilities in Brazil and Argentina. We look at opportunities outside of those two countries. And at this point, we don't have any plans to put up production facilities in other countries. But it's something that we'll continue to think about to monitor as our business down there grows.

componenttextpreview: Henry, as you think about the Flexible Packaging business for you in your developed markets, your established market. And you think about where you sit with your stable of new products and technologies, do you think the gap between you and your nearest co
componenttext: Henry, as you think about the Flexible Packaging business for you in your developed markets, your established market. And you think about where you sit with your stable of new products and technologies, do you think the gap between you and your nearest competition in your key market has expanded, or do you think that competition is, to some degree, catching up on you? And as you answer the question, could you give a few anecdotes or case that would validate your view on the world?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think our product, our new products streamlined, and the combination of some of the technologies and expertise that cited Alcan and that sit in Bemis, together, are going to drive new product development. I think we're maintaining our lead and in fact,
componenttext: I think our product, our new products streamlined, and the combination of some of the technologies and expertise that cited Alcan and that sit in Bemis, together, are going to drive new product development. I think we're maintaining our lead and in fact, I think, we've kind of expanded our lead a little bit over our competition. However, I do think that the timeframe that when you come out with a new product before your competition can copy it is shrinking. So I think our lead in technology is growing. But I think you'll hold that lead for a shorter period of time before people are able to come in and do a mock-up of that. So I mean, that's kind of how I see where we stand with our technology leads. Some of the things you look at that as an anecdote or the examples would be microwavable vegetables. We came out with those very quickly. And in a number of years, we have people that are trying to do some form of mock-ups. We came out quickly with our Stick Packs programs, using easy open features, so that you could tear evenly across and pour the powdered drink out. Others are coming in with copies of that. They can't quite meet the technology that we have in the easy open feature, but they're following along with those products. Those are a couple of examples.

componenttext: Well, a couple of you reasons. One, we've got more facilities now. Two, on our CapEx projects, some of these are major asset purchases, and the delivery schedule for equipment that we buy, for example, is not perfectly predictable. And so as I said before, CapEx doesn't fall neatly into three-month period just because of what we're ordering and who's supplying the assets that we're purchasing.

componenttext: Good day, everyone. Welcome to the Bemis Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] For opening remarks and introductions, I will now turn the call over to the Vice President and Treasurer for Bemis Company, Ms. Melanie Miller. Ms. Miller, please go ahead.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Welcome to the Bemis Company Third Quarter 2010 Conference on October 28, 2010. After today's call, a replay will be available on our website, www.bemis.com, under the Investor Relations section.Joining me for this call today are Be
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Welcome to the Bemis Company Third Quarter 2010 Conference on October 28, 2010. After today's call, a replay will be available on our website, www.bemis.com, under the Investor Relations section.
Joining me for this call today are Bemis Company's President and Chief Executive Officer, Henry Theisen; and our Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Scott Ullem. Today, Scott will begin with his comments on the financial results, followed by Henry with comments on the business.
After our comments, we will answer any questions you have. However, in order to allow everyone an opportunity to participate, we ask that you limit yourself to one question at a time with a related follow-up, and then fall back into the queue for any additional question.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind everyone that statements regarding future performance of the company made in this teleconference are forward-looking and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from historical, expected or projected results due to a variety of factors, including currency fluctuations, changes in raw material cost and availability, industry competition, unexpected consumer buying trends or customer order patterns, our ability to pass along increased costs in our selling prices, costs and integration risks associated with business combinations, interest rate fluctuations and regional economic conditions. A more complete list of risk factors is included in our regular SEC filings, including the most recently filed Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009.
Now I'll turn the call over to Scott Ullem.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melanie, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with the results of the third quarter and the growth that we are experiencing in sales and on the bottom line. We reported earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.56 on a GAAP basis a
componenttext:
Thanks, Melanie, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with the results of the third quarter and the growth that we are experiencing in sales and on the bottom line. We reported earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.56 on a GAAP basis and $0.57 excluding special charges associated with acquisition integration.
This is an increase of about 19% over last year's adjusted earnings per share, and it is within our third quarter guidance range of $0.55 to $0.60 that we provided in July.  My comments this morning will focus on the primary drivers impacting operating profit. I will also provide some color on corporate expenses, cash flow and our focus on improving returns on capital.
Net sales this quarter increased by 44%, including the impact of our Food Americas acquisition on March 1 of this year. To get a better measure of organic growth in the top line, we compared actual sales in the third quarter of 2010 to pro forma sales in the third quarter of 2009. With that comparison, sales increased by about 8% from the depressed sales levels of last year. We estimate that this increase was driven equally by volume improvement and increased price mix.
Currency change translations had no net effect on our sales this quarter. Relative to the U.S. dollar, the weaker euro and pound sterling was offset by the stronger Brazilian real and Mexican peso. Selling prices were generally higher across the board, reflecting the raw material cost increases that we experienced during the first half of 2010.  Volumes were also up in certain flexible packaging categories such as dairy and liquids, dry foods, confectionery and snack, beverage overwrap, health and hygiene, industrial and medical and pharmaceutical. In the Pressure Sensitive Materials segment, which represented about 11% of sales this quarter, we enjoyed a volume recovery in the label category and low to mid-single-digit growth in our higher value-added graphic and technical products.
Sales mix was generally consistent from 2009 to 2010. Last year, we benefited from sales mix improvements during the third quarter, driven by increased sales of higher value-added products that delivered increased margins to the operating profit line as well.  In 2010, we have maintained this sales mix while experiencing volume growth across the majority of our product offerings. Volumes in our European operations continue to be negatively impacted by weak market conditions in that region.
In addition to top line improvements, operating profit is being impacted by several other factors in 2010. First, the lower operating profit margins associated with the newly acquired Food Americas business that have reduced our overall operating margins in 2010. Second, we are on track to record $30 million of cost savings synergies related primarily to SG&A and raw material purchasing synergies. We continue to expect these savings to grow to a run rate of approximately $60 million by the end of 2011.
In addition, our World Class Manufacturing initiatives continue to make important improvements in our cost structure around the world. The discipline that is part of that program ensures that improvements are made and maintained and become the basis for further improvement in the future. Using these initiatives, we have improved our operational efficiency, reduced waste and manufacturing cost and reduced our capital expenditure needs. Over the next few years, we expect these factors to contribute to improved operating profit.
SG&A and R&D costs have increased to reflect the impact of the Food Americas acquisition in 2010. As a percentage of sales, our SG&A rate is decreased by 2% to 8.8% of sales in 2010. R&D, as a percentage of sales, has increased slightly. In both cases, the current run rate is a reasonable proxy for these costs as a percentage of sales going forward.
In the third quarter of 2009, other operating income and expense included $16 million of transaction-related fees. In the third quarter of 2010, we recorded about $1.2 million of such fees. The remaining balances of other operating income and expense included exchange gains and losses and the fiscal incentive income that we earned in Brazil.
Other non-operating income in 2009 reflected the gain on the sale of a building in Brazil and interest income from the investment of the proceeds of the acquisition pre-funding of July 2009. In 2010, other non-operating expense, primarily reflects hedging cost associated with an intercompany loan to our Brazilian subsidiary.
Our tax rate for the third quarter was 36% and we expect this rate to continue through the fourth quarter. We recorded an $833,000 loss in the discontinued operations during the third quarter. These operations were sold during the third quarter on July 13 for $75 million net cash proceeds after selling costs.
We continue to fulfill an obligation to provide the buyer with product to support certain manufacturing needs. Those sales were considered discontinued operations until the sale was completed. Now those sales are included in continuing operations, and the value of these sales currently is approximately $15 million per quarter.
Looking at the fourth financial schedule in the press release titled Operating Profit and Pretax Profit, you'll see a line titled General Corporate Expenses. This line is an accumulation of the cost in pretax profit that are related to general corporate functions. The corporate expenses in the third quarter of 2009 reflect the usually high amount of transaction-related fees incurred. For both the second and third quarters of 2010, we have reported corporate expenses in the $25 million range, and we expect this to be a reasonable run rate for the next year.
Turning to the cash flow statement. It is important to note, cash flow in 2009 benefited substantially from a reduction in working capital, primarily related to a sharp decline in raw material costs. In 2010, raw material costs are somewhat higher, and volume growth in several product categories has caused additional growth in working capital through the summer. As a result, we now expect working capital to be a use of cash for the full year. However, we expect some improvement during the fourth quarter, which is a seasonally stronger quarter for cash flow.
Since we closed the Food Americas acquisition on March 1, we have reduced outstanding debt by $130 million. In addition, we spent $29 million buying back 1 million shares of Bemis common stock. Going forward, we will use a disciplined approach to allocating cash between capital expenditures, acquisitions, debt reduction and share repurchase. Our goal is to generate superior total returns for our shareholders through dividends, payback on internal growth initiatives, acquisitions and the strategic use of our balance sheet.
I'd like to spend a moment on capital expenditures. Through the third quarter, we spent $65 million on CapEx. We now expect our total CapEx for 2010 to approximate $115 million. This is lower than our previous guidance of approximately $140 million and our original guidance in March in the range of $160 million to $170 million, and there are several reasons for this improvement. 
One, we have been very pleased with the assets we acquired with Food Americas. Generally speaking, the net 20 plants that we have added to our plant network are well maintained and modern. But more importantly, we are now able to streamline operations and run our products where they are most productive. This focus on where we run our products and specification management has increased the overall effective capacity of our operations.
Two, our World Class Manufacturing initiatives are providing us better leverage of our existing assets. And three, some of this year's capital projects have been pushed to 2011 simply because projects don't neatly fall into calendar year reporting periods. We still expect CapEx to lag our expected depreciation and amortization levels of about $210 million for this foreseeable future.
Looking ahead, our total year 2010 guidance is $2.10 dollars to $2.15 per share, which is a 12% to 16% improvement over our record 2009 performance of $1.86 per share. This 2010 guidance reflects guidance of $0.48 to $0.53 for the fourth quarter.
We are pleased with the first 10 months of our expanded global operations, and we look forward to continuing strong performance the balance of this year and next.
Now I'll turn it over to Henry for his comments.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Today, I will focus my comments on three main topics, the Food Americas integration, the current business environment, and the 2010 climate for raw materials. The Food Americas acquisition is now seven months old, and we are making gre
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Today, I will focus my comments on three main topics, the Food Americas integration, the current business environment, and the 2010 climate for raw materials. 
The Food Americas acquisition is now seven months old, and we are making great progress with our integration. Our customers have reacted positively to the combined operations, and are focused on achieving a seamless integration, resulting in high-quality customer service and enhanced product innovation. Our ability to consistently deliver quality product to customer's facilities throughout integration process has solidified our position as a reliable packaging supplier.
During the third quarter, our organic sales growth was supported by volume growth in areas where our unique materials offer customers high-performance solutions to suit their packaging needs. This included those higher growth categories that benefit from demand for preparation meals and single-serve beverages, as well as condiments and hard-to-hold sauces. Examples of quick preparation meals would be steam-able frozen vegetables, where the vegetables are microwaved in a package that has incorporated features that allow the steam to build up, to cook the product and then the package softens [ph] and has an easy open future.  Lunch kits, which include individual package components like bread, meat, cheese and condiments, that consumers use to make a deli-style sandwich, shelf-stable microwavable meals with retort packaging, and frozen meal kits that include pre-cooked rice or pasta, vegetables and a meat.  In addition, sales volume in categories that had weakened in 2009 have rebounded a bit this quarter. These include sales of packaging into categories for beverage wraps, confectionery, frozen foods and industrial products. 
In Latin America, our Mexico operations performed better this quarter. We are pleased with the quick response by our management team to streamline specifications and effectively schedule facilities to improve profitability in that region. Our Brazilian operations are performing well, overcoming the competitive disadvantage of the recent strength of the local currency. We continue to see this region as critically important to our international growth strategy. Brazil is experiencing strong economic growth compared to the rest of the world, and the anticipated emergence of stronger consumer demand for protein and healthcare products will create future volume growth and sales mix improvement, opportunities using our most sophisticated product lines.
As we stated in our July conference call, our European operations have been experiencing a difficult environment in 2010, which put pressure on sales volumes and made it challenging to recover the increasing cost of raw materials. Raw material costs have taken an interesting course in 2010. Cost increased during the first quarter of the year, and while specialty resin cost plateaued, commodity resin cost begun to come down again in the latter half of the second quarter. During the third quarter, raw material costs begin to increase once again, but in addition, competition for capacity has created a shortage of oriented polyester film in the market.  Bemis is well supplied and is meeting all of our customers needs. We do not anticipate any production issues as a result of the shortage. However, it has already caused polyester resin and oriented-film prices to increase in the fourth quarter.
I am pleased that our supply chain management group has been able to secure and maintain a sufficient supply of oriented-polyester film to meet the needs of our customers. I am especially pleased with the programs they have put in place to ensure we have a secure supply of it in the future. These increasing raw material costs will put modest pressure on operating margins during the fourth quarter, while our disciplined business model adjusts selling prices to accommodate those increases.
Going forward, we will continue to invest in platforms that support those markets and product lines that value our technology. In the areas where the competitive landscape is more aggressive, our world class manufacturing efforts will continuously improve efficiency and control cost and allow us to compete, grow and improve profitably. 
Now I'd like to open up the call for questions.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first from the line of Sara Magers with Wells Fargo.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a bit more detail on the lower CapEx guidance? I'm just wondering about the reduction in the project shift. And then to follow up on that, could you give us, I guess, an update on the synergies? And it sounds like with the reduced CapEx
componenttext: Could you give us a bit more detail on the lower CapEx guidance? I'm just wondering about the reduction in the project shift. And then to follow up on that, could you give us, I guess, an update on the synergies? And it sounds like with the reduced CapEx and how modern and streamlined these facilities are and your pleasure with how the integration is tracking, but the synergies could possibly get accelerated a bit or you might be  finding a bit more?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, as far as the CapEx spending, we are generating additional capacity by taking a look at where we place our products and what specifications we run. If you look at some of the things that Alcan was really good at was like for instance, foi
componenttext: Well, first off, as far as the CapEx spending, we are generating additional capacity by taking a look at where we place our products and what specifications we run. If you look at some of the things that Alcan was really good at was like for instance, foil laminations, so we can consolidate foiled laminations in certain facilities. We can take a look at where Alcan, for instance, made packaging for processed meats, and we made process meat packaging films, which specifications run best on which equipment and then which plant. So what we're doing is we're generating a lot of capacity by really taking a good look at what our manufacturing footprint is and placing the products that fit best on that footprint in the appropriate place. And we're generating quite a bit of additional capacity to grow our business in almost all the areas. As far as synergies, we're very happy with the synergies. I think we can continue to grow synergies, and I'm very happy. I look forward to $60 million that we promised through 2011 as a run rate.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that, Sara. On synergies, we're right on track with where we thought we would be. In 2010, our focus has been on reducing SG&A, and we made early progress on that, and got after a lot of those SG&A cost reductions even in the first mon
componenttext: I would just add to that, Sara. On synergies, we're right on track with where we thought we would be. In 2010, our focus has been on reducing SG&A, and we made early progress on that, and got after a lot of those SG&A cost reductions even in the first month after we closed on March 1. Then the secondary focus for this year has been in raw material cost savings, resulting from the combination of the two businesses. Next year, what's really going to drive us from the $30 million that we'll book in 2010 to a run rate of about $60 million by the end of 2011 is a lot of the plant consolidation cost savings that we have planned and are expecting to get next year.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So plant consolidation, does that mean putting products in different plants or are you closing plants?
componenttext: So plant consolidation, does that mean putting products in different plants or are you closing plants?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not closing plants. It's optimizing our plant network. We've said all along that is not a capacity reduction acquisition, rather, we're pleased with the additional capacity we picked up. This is merely, as Henry said, optimizing the way we run our busines
componenttext: Not closing plants. It's optimizing our plant network. We've said all along that is not a capacity reduction acquisition, rather, we're pleased with the additional capacity we picked up. This is merely, as Henry said, optimizing the way we run our business across the production capacity around our system, now which includes over 80 production facilities around the world.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Panjabi Ghansham (sic)[Ghansham Panjabi] [Robert W. Baird].
componenttext: We'll go next to Panjabi Ghansham (sic)[Ghansham Panjabi] [Robert W. Baird].

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Curious on whether, is there a strategic need here in Europe, strategic on requirements from your customers to be in Europe in terms of your footprint there? Because it seems like you lack critical mass in there, and is it time to start considering strate
componenttext: Curious on whether, is there a strategic need here in Europe, strategic on requirements from your customers to be in Europe in terms of your footprint there? Because it seems like you lack critical mass in there, and is it time to start considering strategic options for this business.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think it's strategic from our customer base that we have facilities in Europe. We picked up most of those facilities through acquisition. And we bought the Shrink Bag business and there was a plant in Europe we acquired as we went through the
componenttext: Yes, I don't think it's strategic from our customer base that we have facilities in Europe. We picked up most of those facilities through acquisition. And we bought the Shrink Bag business and there was a plant in Europe we acquired as we went through the pressure-sensitive business, we acquired a facility in Valkeakoski, Finland. We acquired a facility from our Clysar operations, but it is long term, a good market for us. We believe long term, those technologies and the products that we make will have a fit in there. I do have to admit that we are by far, very distant to Amcor now. But if you look at our business, the areas that we've invested in are the ones that we put technology in, those are holding up well. They just don't have enough volume yet to offset what we acquired through the acquisition tree.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then also, could you update us on what trends you're seeing in resin by geography, so in North America, Western Europe and also Brazil as well?
componenttext: And then also, could you update us on what trends you're seeing in resin by geography, so in North America, Western Europe and also Brazil as well?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're seeing rising raw material cost in all the regions. It seems a little stronger in Europe, but it's really rising pretty comparatively in all three of those key regions.
componenttext: We're seeing rising raw material cost in all the regions. It seems a little stronger in Europe, but it's really rising pretty comparatively in all three of those key regions.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just piggyback on Ghansham's question regarding Europe, maybe actually one more. Europe, obviously, at least from our vantage point has not been as good of a region, as perhaps the company might have hoped it was or would be back earlier in th
componenttext: I wanted to just piggyback on Ghansham's question regarding Europe, maybe actually one more. Europe, obviously, at least from our vantage point has not been as good of a region, as perhaps the company might have hoped it was or would be back earlier in the decade. And we realize Bemis has terrific technology. We realize a great opportunity to utilize that technology and leverage it over time. But is there a time, maybe not next quarter, but over the next couple of years, where you finally make a decision, look, we have enough opportunities in the U.S. and Latin America where we don't have to keep hitting our heads up against the wall in Europe and make a cut bait or fish decision.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't see that in the near future. I think we still have an opportunity to enhance our business in Europe. We've made the investments in those technologies, and I think we really will see some improvement. But it's not going to come easy. We have also f
componenttext: I don't see that in the near future. I think we still have an opportunity to enhance our business in Europe. We've made the investments in those technologies, and I think we really will see some improvement. But it's not going to come easy. We have also fallen in a time here where the economy of Europe is really hurting us. So I don't know how long can the economy of Europe stay slower. And as that improves, we're going to have a good opportunity to grow. We're not looking at trying to make a major stake in the European market.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've already seen the company fall back capital spending this year, and you haven't even begun to discuss whereas really begin the optimization of the facilities yet, and that's coming next year. Should we expect that even if there's some pushing out int
componenttext: We've already seen the company fall back capital spending this year, and you haven't even begun to discuss whereas really begin the optimization of the facilities yet, and that's coming next year. Should we expect that even if there's some pushing out into 2011 of capital projects that should have hit this year that you can more or less maintain this level of capital spending for the next couple of years?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We will likely spend more in CapEx in 2011 than we will in 2010. But we expect that for some period of time to come, multiple years, we will be investing less in CapEx than our book depreciation amortization, which we think it will be about $210 million i
componenttext: We will likely spend more in CapEx in 2011 than we will in 2010. But we expect that for some period of time to come, multiple years, we will be investing less in CapEx than our book depreciation amortization, which we think it will be about $210 million in 2010.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just curious, Scott, given everything you've said about the acquisition of Food Americas, why that synergy target isn't becoming larger?
componenttext: Just curious, Scott, given everything you've said about the acquisition of Food Americas, why that synergy target isn't becoming larger?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, keep in mind, these are identified cost savings. And they were developed after a lot of work or through a lot of work during the time that we were negotiating the acquisition with Food Americas and the lengthy period of time between signing a defini
componenttext: Well, keep in mind, these are identified cost savings. And they were developed after a lot of work or through a lot of work during the time that we were negotiating the acquisition with Food Americas and the lengthy period of time between signing a definitive agreement and closing the deal in March 1. And so we have a game plan in place that we have been executing. We expect that over time, the same way we do in our regular operations, we will identify further opportunities to take out cost. But the $30 million this year growing to $60 million run rate by the end of 2011 is based on that specific game plan that we put in place with identified cost savings at that time. Again, it's the same way we're running our business and using World Class Manufacturing initiatives to improve our cost position. We expect that we'll be able to do that with the 20 Food Americas facilities that we acquired as well.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It just sounds like you're probably finding a few more opportunities than you expected. If I could, as a follow-on, Henry, can you just talk a little bit about Asia? I mean, I appreciate the fact that Latin America is a very good market for you and certai
componenttext: It just sounds like you're probably finding a few more opportunities than you expected. If I could, as a follow-on, Henry, can you just talk a little bit about Asia? I mean, I appreciate the fact that Latin America is a very good market for you and certainly a growing market and a market where you've got a nice presence, but we've also got a lot of places in Asia that are growing a very, very rapidly and the population base, frankly is just much, much larger.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have an interest in expanding our footprint in Asia. We do spend time trying to find strategic acquisitions like we were lucky enough to do with Dixie Toga in South America. We have been investing. We have three key footprints, our medical packaging pr
componenttext: We have an interest in expanding our footprint in Asia. We do spend time trying to find strategic acquisitions like we were lucky enough to do with Dixie Toga in South America. We have been investing. We have three key footprints, our medical packaging program in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. We recently put in a converting operations just outside Shanghai in supporting of our protein markets, Shrink Bag markets and fresh meat packaging as well as our medical device. And we did acquire a fresh meat packaging facility, if you will, in New Zealand. So we're going to build on those three, and we're going to continue to look for an acquisition that can make sense, one that is, but we're not going to rush there and try to do something that's big and dilutive to the company. But we are interested in that region, and we are trying to explore opportunities to grow.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: We'll go next to the line of Philip Ng with Jefferies.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you guys have a good amount of new products and you've seen pretty good traction. But in the past, you guys have had to walk away from some low margin business. I'm just trying to get a handicap all together when I look at 2011. What type o
componenttext: It sounds like you guys have a good amount of new products and you've seen pretty good traction. But in the past, you guys have had to walk away from some low margin business. I'm just trying to get a handicap all together when I look at 2011. What type of organic growth are you expecting?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Right now, we're in the process, Phil, of putting together our planning for 2011. And I think we'll have more comments in what we see is our growth opportunities and how we're going to approach the market as we conclude our planning session here in the next couple of months.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But in the past, I think you said the long-term stable run rate was like low to mid-single-digit run rate, is that still sustainable going forward, you think?
componenttext: But in the past, I think you said the long-term stable run rate was like low to mid-single-digit run rate, is that still sustainable going forward, you think?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if you think about our end markets and the customers that we serve, they are GDP plus a couple of points kind of growth environments. And that is the same profile that we face as it relates to organic growth opportunities. And so that, I think, what
componenttext: Well, if you think about our end markets and the customers that we serve, they are GDP plus a couple of points kind of growth environments. And that is the same profile that we face as it relates to organic growth opportunities. And so that, I think, what you've seen us do historically is probably a good indicator of what we'll be able to do going forward. But I want to note that -- what's important to note is we are investing not just in areas that represent good organic growth, but areas that represent good opportunity to expand margins. So even in markets that maybe growing at low to mid-single digits, we're investing in platforms where we can get nice pickups in our operating profit margins.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could help us and maybe I missed it, clarify how much Europe was down in terms of EBIT year-over-year?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't usually get in to that sort of detail talking about the specific EBIT margins by region. But clearly, the volumes were down, and total sales were down once again, double-digit year-over-year. They had a pretty good year, even volume wise, in 2009
componenttext: We don't usually get in to that sort of detail talking about the specific EBIT margins by region. But clearly, the volumes were down, and total sales were down once again, double-digit year-over-year. They had a pretty good year, even volume wise, in 2009. The economic conditions really didn't seem to hit our European operations until early 2010. And this has sort of been an ongoing issue for them in 2010, dealing with lower volumes and it's really the lower volumes causing the overhead absorption not to be as good as it was a year ago in addition to higher raw material cost.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess, a follow-up question is, with CapEx coming down and below D&A, at least, for the foreseeable future, I know there's some deleveraging going on as well, but what's the appetite near term for other uses of free cash flow, such as share repurcha
componenttext: And I guess, a follow-up question is, with CapEx coming down and below D&A, at least, for the foreseeable future, I know there's some deleveraging going on as well, but what's the appetite near term for other uses of free cash flow, such as share repurchases or bolt-on M&A acquisitions?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our priorities for cash flow are as follows: first, dividends. We've increased our dividends for the last 27 years. We've paid a dividend since 1922, and you should expect that we're going to continue to pay an increasing dividend over time. Second, we wi
componenttext: Our priorities for cash flow are as follows: first, dividends. We've increased our dividends for the last 27 years. We've paid a dividend since 1922, and you should expect that we're going to continue to pay an increasing dividend over time. Second, we will continue to invest in internal growth initiatives that represent attractive return on investment opportunities. Third, we are looking actively for acquisition opportunities, but those are unpredictable and not something that we can plan quarter-to-quarter as it relates to use of cash flow. What we then do is look at, and we'll continue to do, is look at using cash to pay down debt. We pay down $130 million in debt since the acquisition and to buy back stock. And as we mentioned, we bought back 1 million shares in the third quarter. We do have an authorization to repurchase an additional 3.1 million shares. And we think very carefully about what we do with every dollar of cash flow that comes in.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: And I might have missed this. But as you look at your fourth quarter expectation, which I would imagine were a little bit less than maybe what you were thinking a few months ago, would you say most of the lower, I guess, outlook is tied to volumes in utilization? Or is it tied to the raw material pressures and therefore, it's just a matter of time before you pass those on?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the vast majority is related to the raw materials. And as you know, as we've talked before a lot of those sometimes because of the way our contracts are structured, about 2/3 of them have escalators, de-escalators, and can take up to 90 days to pa
componenttext: I think the vast majority is related to the raw materials. And as you know, as we've talked before a lot of those sometimes because of the way our contracts are structured, about 2/3 of them have escalators, de-escalators, and can take up to 90 days to pass those raw materials through. The other third, we take a look at it, we can pass those through immediately on an order-to-order basis. So it takes us 60 to 90 days to pass that through. So I think that's a little bit of headwinds for us here in the fourth quarter.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I also like to clarify that our guidance throughout the year, we've been raising our total year guidance throughout the year. So as we look at -- I don't think the fourth quarter expectations, our guidance for fourth quarter is lower than we had expected
componenttext: I also like to clarify that our guidance throughout the year, we've been raising our total year guidance throughout the year. So as we look at -- I don't think the fourth quarter expectations, our guidance for fourth quarter is lower than we had expected earlier in the year. I think we had hoped in our July estimate, had some range in there for a various activity with raw material cost. And unfortunately, with raw materials cost going up, we're in the lower half of the range we put out in July. But I think that our range for fourth quarter by itself is really very close to what we've expected for quite a while.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned you will get $30 million, or I think just clarify, are you going to be in the $30 million run rate at the end of this year with synergies or is that what you get for this year? And then if you could just sort of tell us how we would expect t
componenttext: You mentioned you will get $30 million, or I think just clarify, are you going to be in the $30 million run rate at the end of this year with synergies or is that what you get for this year? And then if you could just sort of tell us how we would expect those to phase-in throughout 2011 to get to the $60 million? Is it kind of a straight-line or is it lumpy?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chip. The answer is yes, it's $30 million booked in 2010, which means that the run rate by the end of this year will be higher than $30 million as we go towards that target $60 million run rate by the end of 2011. It's not a perfect straight-line sl
componenttext: Sure, Chip. The answer is yes, it's $30 million booked in 2010, which means that the run rate by the end of this year will be higher than $30 million as we go towards that target $60 million run rate by the end of 2011. It's not a perfect straight-line slope between where we are now and where we will be at the end of 2011. There is some lumpiness to it, but you'll see us gradually grow from where we are now to the $60 million range a year from now.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit of about, I guess, price recovery in Q4. Are you expecting, I guess, price cost parity in the quarter? And then to follow up on that, I'm wondering what your assumption is regarding resins for the balance of the year.

componenttext: And normally, the way that our business model works after about three months or so, pretty much the majority of our selling prices have been adjusted to be at parity with the raw material costs.

componenttext: And then just quickly, I'm wondering about how Q4 has been trending so far in terms of demand. From what I understand, I think that -- isn't October typically one of the larger months of the quarter? I'm just wondering what you're seeing so far.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: The demand that we have going to the fourth quarter is strong. We feel good about it. And you're right, our October is our big month, and then you kind of go up through the holiday seasons, and that's what always makes the fourth quarter a little slower than some of the others. But we feel very good with our volume and our backlogs going into the fourth quarter.

componenttext: I want to come back to capital spending and cash flow, and these questions. Before, Scott, when I was going through the Q&A with you, I just wanted to ask a follow on. headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of uses of cash, I guess, piggy-backing the earlier question from Al, you enumerated the normal uses of cash. Obviously, the company has had a great dividend track record you've made acquisitions, you want to invest in places where you're get
componenttext: And in terms of uses of cash, I guess, piggy-backing the earlier question from Al, you enumerated the normal uses of cash. Obviously, the company has had a great dividend track record you've made acquisitions, you want to invest in places where you're getting high margins and returns and ultimately, you also buy back stock. As you sit here today relative maybe Bemis' priorities on cash flow a few years ago, do you think any one of those four or five are more important on a going-forward basis than might have been the case previously?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, we've got a lot more debt now than we did before. Granted, we also have a lot of additional earnings, but we think carefully about managing our debt levels. We're comfortable with where we are today. But we also want to make sure
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, we've got a lot more debt now than we did before. Granted, we also have a lot of additional earnings, but we think carefully about managing our debt levels. We're comfortable with where we are today. But we also want to make sure we preserve flexibility for acquisitions that we expect will come. But it's critically important that we think carefully about every dollar that comes in the house, and whether we apply that to debt paydown. And right now, we do not have any maturities that are coming quickly. The next bond that matures is in the spring of 2012. And as we've said multiple times, we are not just going to sit on cash. And so that's the reason why we'll look towards share repurchases in the public market versus paying down commercial paper. And at the same time, preserving the flexibility that we need to make acquisitions.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Chris Manuel, KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Chris Manuel, KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you. The first is on Brazil. With all of the -- we're hearing quite a bit of chatter out of folks down there that the packaging mix is evolving and changing so, so quickly. And with all of your -- to more towards flexible packaging and t
componenttext: Two questions for you. The first is on Brazil. With all of the -- we're hearing quite a bit of chatter out of folks down there that the packaging mix is evolving and changing so, so quickly. And with all of your -- to more towards flexible packaging and things of that nature, with your Dixie Toga business down there that -- is there an opportunity or maybe you could talk about what the opportunities over the next couple of years for that business to have 10%, 15%, 20% up volume levels to capture a lot of these conversion? So I guess the question is, could you give us a little color on what's happening in Brazil and maybe where volume levels are now?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brazil is in an exciting part of our growth strategy, going forward. We were lucky enough to acquire Dixie Toga, which is the number one flexible packaging company in Latin America. We're well positioned. It's been a strategy all along to have that kind o
componenttext: Brazil is in an exciting part of our growth strategy, going forward. We were lucky enough to acquire Dixie Toga, which is the number one flexible packaging company in Latin America. We're well positioned. It's been a strategy all along to have that kind of a base to work from. We always felt that as the population becomes more middle-class, that they're going to want the things that we all have here. Food safety, medical sterility are all important. We have invested in the Shrink Bag business. We've invested in putting assets into Brazil that can grow in those key market areas. And we look forward to some very good growth, not just in some of the more older established Dixie Toga product lines, but also with our pharmaceutical business that we gained through the acquisition of Alcan, through the technologies that we could put into it in the packaging of protein. Also the success, all the convenience features that we have. And we look to grow our Medical Device business down there also. So we look for some exciting growth in Brazil, especially in those key areas that we like to invest in.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up question had to do with your sensitive business. And I apologize because I jumped on the call a little late if you already talked about this. But the trajectory, as we've gone through the year, has moved down a bit, as you look at th
componenttext: And then my follow-up question had to do with your sensitive business. And I apologize because I jumped on the call a little late if you already talked about this. But the trajectory, as we've gone through the year, has moved down a bit, as you look at the EBIT contribution quarter-by-quarter. Is there anything unusual happening there that is driving that, or should we rebound back to the upper single digit level on a go-forward basis?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it should rebound back to the upper single digits on a go-forward basis. We've had good volume growth this year compared to last year in our Pressure Sensitive business. We have had some cost pressures in Pressure Sensitive in raw materials that w
componenttext: I think it should rebound back to the upper single digits on a go-forward basis. We've had good volume growth this year compared to last year in our Pressure Sensitive business. We have had some cost pressures in Pressure Sensitive in raw materials that we're working hard to pass through right now, much like we have in the flexible packaging area.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Margins in that business are also very impacted by sales mix, which could vary from one quarter to the other. And I would say, second quarter is generally a pretty strong margin quarter for Pressure Sensitive, because of the strength of the sales in graph
componenttext: Margins in that business are also very impacted by sales mix, which could vary from one quarter to the other. And I would say, second quarter is generally a pretty strong margin quarter for Pressure Sensitive, because of the strength of the sales in graphic and technical products in that particular part of the year.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to the from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: On Pressure Sensitive, we've heard from several trade contacts recently that you have also gone into the market with some pricing increases. If you mentioned it already on the call, I apologize I didn't hear it. But could you comment on that, if that is correct, in fact?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't normally talk about those particular events on a conference call or in press releases. We do have very strong discipline throughout Bemis Company's Flexible and Pressure Sensitive to the extent that we have raw material cost increases, we directl
componenttext: We don't normally talk about those particular events on a conference call or in press releases. We do have very strong discipline throughout Bemis Company's Flexible and Pressure Sensitive to the extent that we have raw material cost increases, we directly increase selling prices as soon as possible in areas where we can competitively. So I think hopefully, that addresses your question. We've had raw material cost increase in chemical throughout both of our business segments over the last couple of months. So perhaps, that's what you're referring to.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: You had mentioned that the corporate spending run rate should be more or less $25 million, if I heard you correctly, over the next four quarters, or I believe into 2011 is what you mentioned. Does that suggest that, that's the appropriate run rate into the future, or was that perhaps after 2011, there may be some ability for that level of spending to decline. And if that's the case, what perhaps could it get to in your corporate environment?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's the right expectation for the foreseeable future. And there's a movement potentially between corporate expenses and what gets allocated to our two reportable segments. But based upon the way you probably get your model set up right now, that $25 mi
componenttext: That's the right expectation for the foreseeable future. And there's a movement potentially between corporate expenses and what gets allocated to our two reportable segments. But based upon the way you probably get your model set up right now, that $25 million is a good assumption, going forward.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: We'll take a follow up from Al Kabili with Macquarie.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on resin. And normally, resin peaked in North America around the spring and then fell. And then, normally, you would have benefited from the lag on the way down as well. And it just doesn't seem like this time around, you've see
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on resin. And normally, resin peaked in North America around the spring and then fell. And then, normally, you would have benefited from the lag on the way down as well. And it just doesn't seem like this time around, you've seen that temporary lag benefit. And I'm wondering if you could just help us with what's happened there, things on the specialty resins that's overwhelming that if you could just help us think about that.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Before I let Henry talk a little bit resin cost, in the second quarter, you're right that, that's the trajectory that resin cost were going. There were increasing in the first quarter and then started to decrease in May. But those were really -- the decre
componenttext: Before I let Henry talk a little bit resin cost, in the second quarter, you're right that, that's the trajectory that resin cost were going. There were increasing in the first quarter and then started to decrease in May. But those were really -- the decreases were coming primarily in the commodity resins. And because they started decreasing half way through the second quarter, some of that benefit would've been received in the second quarter. So really muted the impact of the higher raw material cost going into the second quarter, and then the benefit that you normally would have expected in the third quarter, it really only benefited the first parts of the third quarter, I would say, on the commodity side.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's a good explanation of what's going on. A lot of it just revolves around what is the exact date at which the escalator, de-escalator passes through. And we kind of cross ourselves here in the second and third quarter with falling and increas
componenttext: I think that's a good explanation of what's going on. A lot of it just revolves around what is the exact date at which the escalator, de-escalator passes through. And we kind of cross ourselves here in the second and third quarter with falling and increasing various customers who have different times than those escalator, de-escalators fire.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow up on an earlier question is with pricing catching up, is resin a headwind then in the fourth quarter and your outlook? And do you expect them by the end of the quarter, your pricing should catch up?
componenttext: And then just a follow up on an earlier question is with pricing catching up, is resin a headwind then in the fourth quarter and your outlook? And do you expect them by the end of the quarter, your pricing should catch up?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a modest headwind here in the fourth quarter and our pricing should catch up going into 2011.
componenttext: I think it's a modest headwind here in the fourth quarter and our pricing should catch up going into 2011.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to the line of David Rose with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to the line of David Rose with Citigroup.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Dave Rose, on for Tim Thein. I'm not sure if you've talked about this before, but the Alcan acquisition from what I understand, we didn't get a good look as to what sort of pensions you had to take over as part of that. So I'm wondering if you cou
componenttext: This is Dave Rose, on for Tim Thein. I'm not sure if you've talked about this before, but the Alcan acquisition from what I understand, we didn't get a good look as to what sort of pensions you had to take over as part of that. So I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about where you expect pension contributions and/or expense to go maybe not in the fourth quarter, but in 2011 and how you think that will impact your cash flow going forward?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I can address that. In the Alcan acquisition, we actually negotiated an asset purchase for the majority of the acquisition. And so there were no additional pension or post retiree medical liabilities that we took on with that. All of those employees
componenttext: Sure. I can address that. In the Alcan acquisition, we actually negotiated an asset purchase for the majority of the acquisition. And so there were no additional pension or post retiree medical liabilities that we took on with that. All of those employees of Alcan came into Bemis Company as new employees of Bemis into our current benefit plan. As far as pension contributions going forward, we had in the first quarter of this year a small $15 million pension contribution. It's our focus to maintain roughly 100% funded status in both of our pension plan, and that helped us get there for 2010. Going into 2011, again, I would anticipate at this point, there's no required contribution, but depending on what the discount rate is at the end of the year and what the funded status ends up at, we may decide given our cash flow projections to put some small amount into the pension plan in 2011. But again, no required contributions. And pension expense grew from 2009 to 2010. Given what the discount rates are looking like now, I would anticipate that it's appropriate to estimate an increase again for 2011. But we don't really know until we get to December 31 and see where the discount rates end up. So at this point, at least, I would expect the pension expense to be about the same as where we are in 2010, which is roughly, I think, $20 million to $25 million, and likely a little bit higher than that.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow on with regards to deferred taxes, I know that it was part of the acquisition purchase price. How are those going to flow into cash flow over time? I know for the first couple of quarter that you've owned Alcan, that's been fairly fla
componenttext: And then as a follow on with regards to deferred taxes, I know that it was part of the acquisition purchase price. How are those going to flow into cash flow over time? I know for the first couple of quarter that you've owned Alcan, that's been fairly flat within cash flow. Is that a line item that you should expect to see increase next year?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the deferred tax, the cash flows of deferred taxes or the cash flows of the tax benefit that we received in the Alcan acquisition because of the fact that we structured it as an asset purchase, those cash benefit, the net present value over
componenttext: With regard to the deferred tax, the cash flows of deferred taxes or the cash flows of the tax benefit that we received in the Alcan acquisition because of the fact that we structured it as an asset purchase, those cash benefit, the net present value over this is about $80 million to $100 million. And that's expected to roll into cash flow over the life of those assets. And as you look at that, the best way to model that is probably to say if you divide it evenly over seven years, you won't be too far off in any one year. Obviously, there's some that would go for substantially longer than that. But really, the bulk of it will be received over the next seven years, so not a dramatic cash flow improvement in any one year, but we will get it in the near term.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: We'll go next to Chris Manuel of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

componenttextpreview: I just had one follow up. I realized when I went into Brazil questions, we missed one part. And that was could you talk a little bit about what the volume trajectory has been like the last couple of quarters? I know we talked about a lot of opportunity. B
componenttext: I just had one follow up. I realized when I went into Brazil questions, we missed one part. And that was could you talk a little bit about what the volume trajectory has been like the last couple of quarters? I know we talked about a lot of opportunity. But do you think that over the next two, three, four years, there's as an opportunity for that to be, given ahead of all the conversion coming, there are double-digit type volume environment for you down in Brazil?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start by saying what 2010 volumes have been like and if you think about Brazil, remember, their winter is in North America’s summer and vice versa. What we saw was really strong volume double-digit nice volume growth in Brazil year-over-year in t
componenttext: Let me start by saying what 2010 volumes have been like and if you think about Brazil, remember, their winter is in North America’s summer and vice versa. What we saw was really strong volume double-digit nice volume growth in Brazil year-over-year in the first half of 2010. And now in the third quarter, volume was not as big a driver, not as strong as it was before. But it's also the latter part of winter in the third quarter in Brazil. So it's not the strongest time for their products. They're coming in now to their strong summer season, as we enter into our fourth quarter and first quarter. The Huhtamaki acquisition we made last year really focused on a lot of ice cream packaging, which is obviously a big summertime product. And they have a lot of powdered drink mix and things like that. So in any event, I think while the third quarter was slower year-over-year volume improvement, we have seen some really strong volume improvement year-to-date in 2010. And would expect that to continue, going forward over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would expect that as Melanie described it, good double-digit growth in those quarters and then slow down. The next trend that she's talking about in 2010 should continue into 2011 and 2012 for us.
componenttext: I would expect that as Melanie described it, good double-digit growth in those quarters and then slow down. The next trend that she's talking about in 2010 should continue into 2011 and 2012 for us.

componenttext: We'll go next to Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.

componenttextpreview: Yes, Brazil can fund its own growth, and Brazil has taken on debt in the past to make certain acquisitions by another joint venture partners and otherwise. And we've repatriated cash from Brazil in the years past. And so it is a net cash flow generator, a
componenttext: Yes, Brazil can fund its own growth, and Brazil has taken on debt in the past to make certain acquisitions by another joint venture partners and otherwise. And we've repatriated cash from Brazil in the years past. And so it is a net cash flow generator, and can continue to fund its own, certainly, its own CapEx.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then would you also -- I think you picked up some assets in Argentina with the Food Americas deal. But would you see kind of moving that footprint into other countries in Latin America? And if so, what countries would be near the top of the list?
componenttext: And then would you also -- I think you picked up some assets in Argentina with the Food Americas deal. But would you see kind of moving that footprint into other countries in Latin America? And if so, what countries would be near the top of the list?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we serve other countries in South America through our production facilities in Brazil and Argentina. We look at opportunities outside of those two countries. And at this point, we don't have any plans to put up production facilities in other countri
componenttext: Well, we serve other countries in South America through our production facilities in Brazil and Argentina. We look at opportunities outside of those two countries. And at this point, we don't have any plans to put up production facilities in other countries. But it's something that we'll continue to think about to monitor as our business down there grows.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Henry, as you think about the Flexible Packaging business for you in your developed markets, your established market. And you think about where you sit with your stable of new products and technologies, do you think the gap between you and your nearest co
componenttext: Henry, as you think about the Flexible Packaging business for you in your developed markets, your established market. And you think about where you sit with your stable of new products and technologies, do you think the gap between you and your nearest competition in your key market has expanded, or do you think that competition is, to some degree, catching up on you? And as you answer the question, could you give a few anecdotes or case studies that would validate your view on the world?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think our product, our new products streamlined, and the combination of some of the technologies and expertise that sat in Alcan and that sit in Bemis, together, are going to drive new product development. I think we're maintaining our lead and in fact,
componenttext: I think our product, our new products streamlined, and the combination of some of the technologies and expertise that sat in Alcan and that sit in Bemis, together, are going to drive new product development. I think we're maintaining our lead and in fact, I think, we've kind of expanded our lead a little bit over our competition. However, I do think that the timeframe that when you come out with a new product before your competition can copy it is shrinking. So I think our lead in technology is growing. But I think you'll hold that lead for a shorter period of time before people are able to come in and do a mock-up of that. So I mean, that's kind of how I see where we stand with our technology leads. Some of the things you look at that as an anecdote or the examples would be microwavable vegetables. We came out with those very quickly. And in a number of years, we have people that are trying to do some form of mock-ups. We came out quickly with our Stick Pack programs, using easy open features, so that you could tear evenly across and pour the powdered drink out. Others are coming in with copies of that. They can't quite meet the technology that we have in the easy open feature, but they're following along with those products. Those are a couple of examples.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: The CapEx guidance, it looks like you guys will be spending quite a bit more money in Q4 than you have on a run rate basis in the past three quarters of the year. Is there anything special that's happening in Q4? And I was just wondering what you're expenditures will be on.

componenttext: Because right now, it looks like you'd be spending a little over $50 million in Q4 given your guidance, where as in past quarters, it's running from anywhere from $17 million to $25 million. It just seems like a substantial jump off, and I'm just wondering why.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of you reasons. One, we've got more facilities now. Two, on our CapEx projects, some of these are major asset purchases, and the delivery schedule for equipment that we buy, for example, is not perfectly predictable. And so as I said before
componenttext: Well, a couple of you reasons. One, we've got more facilities now. Two, on our CapEx projects, some of these are major asset purchases, and the delivery schedule for equipment that we buy, for example, is not perfectly predictable. And so as I said before, CapEx doesn't fall neatly into three-month period just because of what we're ordering and who's supplying the assets that we're purchasing.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
