componenttext: Good day everyone. Welcome to the Bemis third quarter 2010 earnings release conference call. This call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I will now like to turn the call over to the Vice President and Treasurer for Bemis Company, Ms. Melanie Miller. Ms Miller, please go ahead.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Welcome to the Bemis company third quarter 2010 conference call. Today is October 28th, 2010. After today’s call a replay will be available on our website, www.bemis.com under the Investor Relations section. Joining me for this call
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Welcome to the Bemis company third quarter 2010 conference call. Today is October 28th, 2010. After today’s call a replay will be available on our website, www.bemis.com under the Investor Relations section. Joining me for this call today are Bemis Company's President and Chief Executive Officer, Henry Theisen, and our Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Scott Ullem.
Today, Scott will begin with his comments on the financial results followed by Henry with comments on the business. After our comments, we will answer any questions you have. However, in order to allow everyone an opportunity to participate, we ask that you limit yourself to one question at a time with a related follow-up and then fall back into the queue for any additional questions.
Before we begin, I’d like to remind everyone that statements regarding future performance of the company made in this teleconference are forward-looking, and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from historical, expected or projected results due to a variety of factors, including currency fluctuations, changes in raw material costs and availability, industry competition, unexpected consumer buying trends or customer order patterns, our ability to pass along increased costs in our selling prices, costs and integration risks associated with business combinations, interest rate fluctuations and regional economic conditions.
A more complete list of risk factors is included in our regular SEC filing including the most recently filed Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Scott Ullem.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melanie, and good morning everyone. We are pleased with the results of the third quarter and the growth that we are experiencing in sales and on the bottom line. We reported earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.56 on a GAAP basis an
componenttext:
Thanks, Melanie, and good morning everyone. We are pleased with the results of the third quarter and the growth that we are experiencing in sales and on the bottom line. We reported earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.56 on a GAAP basis and $0.57 excluding special charges associated with acquisition integration. This is an increase of about 19% over last year's adjusted earnings per share and it is within our third quarter guidance range of $0.55 to $0.60 that we provided in July. My comments this morning will focus on the primary drivers impacting operating profit. I will also provide some color on corporate expenses, cash flow and our focus on improving returns on capital.
Net sales this quarter increased by 44% including the impact of our Food Americas acquisition on March 1 of this year. To get a better measure of organic growth in the topline, we compared actual sales in the third quarter of 2010 to pro forma sales in the third quarter of 2009. With that comparison, sales increased by about 8% from the depressed sales levels of last year. We estimate that this increase was driven equally by a volume improvement and increased price mix. Currency exchange translations had no net effect on our sales this quarter, relative to the US dollar, the weaker euro and pound sterling was offset by the stronger Brazilian real and Mexican peso.
Selling prices were generally higher across-the-board reflecting the raw material cost increases that we experienced during the first half of 2010. Volumes were also up in certain flexible packaging categories such as diary and liquids, dry foods, confectionery and snack, beverage overwrap, health and hygiene, industrial and medical and pharmaceutical. In the Pressure Sensitive Material segment which represented about 11% of sales this quarter, we enjoyed a volume recovery in the label category in low to mid-single digit growth in our higher value-added graphic and technical products. Sales mix was generally consistent from 2009 to 2010.
Last year we benefited from sales mix improvements during the third quarter driven by increased sales of higher value-added products that delivered increased margins to the operating profit line as well. In 2010, we have maintained this sales mix while experiencing volume growth across the majority of our product offerings. Volumes in our European operations continued to be negatively impacted by weak market conditions in that region. In addition to topline improvements, operating profit is being impacted by several other factors in 2010. First, the lower operating profit margins associated with the newly acquired Food Americas business that have reduced our overall operating margins in 2010.
Second, we are on track to record $30 million of cost savings synergies related primarily to SG&A and raw material purchasing synergies. We continue to expect these savings to grow to a run rate of approximately $60 million by the end of 2011. In addition, our world-class manufacturing initiatives continue to make important improvements in our cost structure around the world. The discipline that is part of that program ensures that improvements are made and maintained and become the basis for further improvement in the future. Using these initiatives, we have improved our operational efficiency, reduced waste and manufacturing costs and reduced our capital expenditure needs. Over the next few years we expect these factors to contribute through improved operating profit.
SG&A and R&D costs have increased to reflect the impact of the Food Americas acquisition in 2010. As a percentage of sales, our SG&A rate has decreased by 2% to 8.8% of sales in 2010. R&D as a percentage of sales has increased slightly. In both cases, the current run rate is a reasonable proxy for these costs as a percentage of sales going forward. In the third quarter of 2009, other operating income and expense included $16 million of transaction related fees. In the third quarter of 2010, we recorded about $1.2 million of such fees. The remaining balances of other operating income and expense included exchange gains and losses in the fiscal incentive income that we earned in Brazil.
Other non-operating income in 2009 reflected the gain on the sale of a building in Brazil and interest income from the investment of the proceeds of the acquisition pre-funding of July 2009. In 2010, other non-operating expense primarily reflects hedging costs associated with an intercompany loan to our Brazilian subsidiary. Our tax rate for the third quarter was 36% and we expect this rate to continue through the fourth quarter. We recorded an $833,000 loss in the discontinued operations during the third quarter. These operations were sold during the third quarter on July 13 for $75 million net cash proceeds after selling costs. We continue to fulfill an obligation to provide the buyer with product to support certain manufacturing needs.
Those sales were considered discontinued operations until the sale was completed. Now those sales are included in continuing operations and the value of these sales currently is approximately $15 million per quarter. Looking at the fourth financial schedule in the press release titled operating profit and pre-tax profit, you will see a line titled general corporate expenses. This line is an accumulation of the costs in pre-tax profit that are related to general corporate functions. The corporate expenses in the third quarter of 2009 reflect the unusually high amount of transaction related fees incurred. For both the second and third quarters of 2010, we have reported corporate expenses in the $25 million range and we expect this to be a reasonable run rate for the next year.
Turning to the cash flow statement, it is important to note, cash flow in 2009 benefited substantially from a reduction in working capital primarily related to a sharp decline in raw material costs. In 2010, raw material costs are somewhat higher and volume growth in several product categories has caused additional growth in working capital through the summer. As a result, we now expect working capital to be a use of cash for the full year. However, we expect some improvement during the fourth quarter which is a seasonally stronger quarter for cash flow. Since we closed the Food Americas acquisition on March 1, we have reduced outstanding debt by $130 million. In addition, we spent $29 million buying back 1 million shares of Bemis common stock. Going forward, we will use a disciplined approach to allocating cash between capital expenditures, acquisitions, debt reduction and share repurchase. Our goal is to generate superior total returns for our shareholders through dividends, payback on internal growth initiatives, acquisitions and the strategic use of our balance sheet.
I would like to spend a moment on capital expenditures. Through the third quarter, we spent $65 million on CapEx. We now expect our total CapEx for 2010 to approximate $115 million. This is lower than our previous guidance of approximately $140 million and our original guidance in March in the range of $160 million to $170 million, and there are several reasons for this improvement. One, we have been very pleased with the assets we acquired with Food Americas. Generally speaking, the net 20 plants that we have added to our plant network are well maintained and modern. But more importantly, we are now able to streamline operations and run our products where they are most productive. This focus on where we run our products and specification management has increased the overall effective capacity of our operations. Two, our world-class manufacturing initiatives are providing us better leverage of our existing assets. And three, some of this year's capital projects have been pushed to 2011 simply because projects don't neatly fall into calendar year reporting periods. We still expect CapEx to lag or expected depreciation and amortization levels of about $210 million for this foreseeable future.
Looking ahead, our total year 2010 guidance is $2.10 to $2.15 per share, which is a 12% to 16% improvement over our record 2009 performance of $1.86 per share. This 2010 guidance reflects guidance of $0.48 to $0.53 for the fourth quarter. We are pleased with the first ten months of our expanded global operations and we look forward to continuing strong performance, the balance of this year and next. Now, I'll turn it over to Henry for his comments.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Today, I will focus my comments on three main topics, the Food Americas integration, the current business environment and the 2010 climate for raw materials. The Food Americas acquisition is now seven months old and we are making great p
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Today, I will focus my comments on three main topics, the Food Americas integration, the current business environment and the 2010 climate for raw materials. The Food Americas acquisition is now seven months old and we are making great progress with our integration. Our customers have reacted positively to the combined operations and are focused on achieving a seamless integration, resulting in high quality customer service and enhanced product innovation. Our ability to consistently deliver quality products to customer’s facilities throughout the integration process has solidified our position as a reliable packaging supplier.
During the third quarter, our organic sales growth was supported by volume growth in areas where our unique materials offered customers high-performance solutions to suit their packaging needs. This included those higher growth categories that benefit from demand for quick preparation meals and single-served beverages as well as condiments and hard-to-hold sauces. Examples of quick preparation meals would be steamable frozen vegetables, where the vegetables are microwaved in a package that has incorporated features that allow the steam to build up to cook the product and then the package self-vents that has an easy open feature. Lunch kits, which include individual package components like bread, meat, cheese and condiments that consumers use to make a daily style sandwich, shelf-stable microwaveable meals, with retort packaging and frozen meal kits that include pre-cooked rice or pasta, vegetables and the meat. In addition, sales volume in categories that had weakened in 2009 have rebounded a bit this quarter. These include sales of packaging into categories for beverage wraps, confectionery, processed foods and industrial products.
In Latin America, our Mexico operations performed better this quarter. We are pleased with the quick response by our management team to streamline specifications and effectively schedule facilities to improve profitability in that region. Our Brazilian operations are performing well, overcoming the competitive disadvantage of the recent strength of the local currency. We continue to see this region as critically important to our international growth strategy. Brazil is experiencing strong economic growth compared to the rest of the world and the anticipated emergence of stronger consumer demand for protein and healthcare products will create future volume growth and sales mix improvement, opportunities using our most sophisticated product lines.
As we stated in our July conference call, our European operations have been experiencing a difficult environment in 2010, which has put pressure on sales volumes and made it challenging to recover the increase in cost of raw materials. Raw material costs have been, have taken an interesting course in 2010. Cost increase during the first quarter of the year and while specialty resin plateaued, commodity resin costs began to come down again in the latter half of the second quarter. During the third quarter raw material costs begin to increase once again but in addition, competition for capacity has created a shortage of oriented polyester film in the market. Bemis is well supplied and is meeting all of our customers’ needs. We do not anticipate any production issues as a result of this shortage. However it has already caused polyester resin and oriented film prices to increase in the fourth quarter.
I am pleased that our supply chain management group has been able to secure and maintain a sufficient supply of orient polyester film to meet the needs of our customers. I am especially pleased with the programs we have put in place to ensure we have a secure supply of it in the future. These increasing raw material costs will put modest pressure on operating margins during the fourth quarter while our disciplined business model adjusts selling prices to accommodate those increases. Going forward, we will continue to invest in platforms that support those markets and product lines that value our technology. In areas where the competitive landscape is more aggressive, our world-class manufacturing efforts will continuously improve efficiency and control costs and allow us to compete, grow and improve profitably. Now, I would like to open up the call for questions.

componenttext: Well, first off, as far as the CapEx spending, we found additional UV [ph] are generating additional capacity by taking a look at where we place our products and what specifications we run. If you look at some of the things that Alcan was really good at, was like for instance foil laminations. So we can consolidate foil laminations in certain facilities. We can take a look at where Alcan for instance made packaging for processed meats, and we made processed meat packaging films, which specifications run best on which equipment and in which plant, so what we're doing is we are generating a lot of capacity by really taking a good look at what our manufacturing footprint is and placing the products that fit best on that footprint in the appropriate place and we are generating quite a bit of additional capacity to grow our business in almost all the areas. As far as synergies, we are very happy with the synergies. I think we can continue to grow synergies and I am very happy and very - look forward to $60 million that we promised through 2011 as a run rate.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I will just add to that, Sara. On synergies, we're right on track where we thought we would be. In 2010 our focus has been on reducing SG&A and we made early progress on that and got after a lot of those SG&A cost reductions even in the first month after
componenttext: I will just add to that, Sara. On synergies, we're right on track where we thought we would be. In 2010 our focus has been on reducing SG&A and we made early progress on that and got after a lot of those SG&A cost reductions even in the first month after we closed on March 1. Then, the secondary focus for this year has been in raw material cost savings resulting from the combination of the two businesses. Next year, what is really going to drive us from the $30 million that we will book in 2010 to a run rate of about $60 million by the end of 2011 as a lot of the plant consolidation cost savings that we have planned and are expecting to get next year.

But, it is long-term a good market for us. We believe long-term to have technologies in the products that we make will have a fit in there, I do have to admit that we are by far very distant to Amcor now but if you look at our business, the areas that we have invested, in the ones that we have put technology in. Those are holding up well, they just don't have enough volume yet to offset what we acquired through the acquisition tree.

componenttext: How are you doing .I wanted to just piggyback on Ghansham's question regarding Europe, or maybe ask you one more. Europe obviously, at least from our vantage point, has not been as good of a region as perhaps the Company might have hoped it was or would be back earlier in the decade, and we realize Bemis has terrific technology. We realized there are great opportunities to utilize that technology and leverage it over time, but is there a time maybe not next quarter, but over the next couple years where you finally make a decision, and say look we have enough opportunities in the US and Latin America where we don't have to keep hitting our heads up against the wall in Europe, and make a cut bait or fish decision?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't see that in the near future. I'd think we still have an opportunity to enhance our business in Europe. We have made investments in those technologies and I think we really will see some improvement but it is not going to come easy. We have al
componenttext: Yes, I don't see that in the near future. I'd think we still have an opportunity to enhance our business in Europe. We have made investments in those technologies and I think we really will see some improvement but it is not going to come easy. We have also fallen on a time here where the economy of Europe is really hurting us. So, I don't know how long can the economy of Europe stay, stay slower and as that proves we're going to have a good opportunity to grow. We're not looking at trying to make a major stake in the European market.

componenttext: Well, keep in mind these are identified cost savings and they were developed after a lot of work or through lot of work during the time that we were negotiating the acquisition of Food Americas and the lengthy period of time between signing the definitive agreement and closing the deal on March 1. And so we have a game plan in place that we have been executing. We expect that over time, the same what we do in our regular operations, we will identify further opportunities to take out costs. But the $30 million this year growing to $60 million run rate by the end of 2011 is based on that specific game plan that we put in place with identified cost savings at that time and it is, again it's just the same way we're running our business and using world-class manufacturing initiatives to improve our cost position. We expect that we will be able to do that with the 20 Food Americas facilities that we acquired as well.

I mean I appreciate the fact that Latin America is a very good market for you. It's certainly a growing market and a market where you've got a nice presence, but we've also got a lot of places in Asia that are growing very, very rapidly, and the population base frankly is just much, much larger.

componenttext: We have an interest in expanding our footprint in Asia. We do spend time trying to find strategic acquisitions like we were lucky enough to do with Dixie Toga in South America. We have been investing, we have three key footprints. Our medical packaging program in Kuala Lumpur Malaysia, we recently put in a converting operation just outside Shanghai in supporting of our protein markets, shrink bag markets and fresh meat packaging as well as our medical device, and we did acquire a fresh meat packaging facility if you will in New Zealand so we're going to build on those three and we are going to continue to look for foreign acquisition that can make sense, one that is, but we're not going to rush there and try to do something that's big and dilutive to the company. But we are interested in that region and we are trying to explore opportunities to grow.

componenttext: Well, if you think about our end markets and our, and the customers that we serve, they are GDP plus a couple of points kind of growth environments and that is the same profile that we face as it relates to organic growth opportunities. And so that, I think what you have seen us do historically is probably a good indicator of what we will be able to do going forward. I want to note that, what is important to note is, we're investing not just in areas that represent good organic growth but areas that represent good opportunity to expand margins. So even in markets that may be growing in at low to mid-single digits, we're investing in platforms where we can get nice pick-ups in our operating profit margins.

componenttext: We don't usually get into that sort of detail talking about the specific EBIT margins by region but clearly the volumes were down and the total sales were down once again double-digit year-over-year. They had a pretty good year, even volume wise in 2009, economic conditions really did not seem to hit our European operations until early 2010 and this has sort of been an ongoing issue for them in 2010 dealing with lower volumes and it is really the lower volumes causing the overhead absorption not to be as good as it was a year ago, in addition to higher raw material costs.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Okay. And I guess a follow-up question is with CapEx coming down and below D&A, at least for the foreseeable future, what's the appetite, I know there's some de-leveraging going on as well, but what's the appetite near term for other uses of free cash flow such as share repurchases or bolt-on M&A acquisitions? Thanks.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, thank you Al. Our priorities for cash flow are as follows. First dividends, we have increased our dividends for the last 27 years. We paid our dividends since 1922 and you should expect that we're going to continue to pay an increasing dividend over
componenttext: Sure, thank you Al. Our priorities for cash flow are as follows. First dividends, we have increased our dividends for the last 27 years. We paid our dividends since 1922 and you should expect that we're going to continue to pay an increasing dividend over time. Second, we will continue to invest in internal growth initiatives that represent attractive return on investment opportunities. Third, we are looking actively for acquisition opportunities. But those are unpredictable and not something that we can plan quarter-to-quarter as it relates to use of cash flow. What we then do is look at and will continue to do is look at using cash to pay down debt. We paid down $130 million in debt since the acquisition and buyback stock and as we mentioned we got back 1 million shares in the third quarter. We do have an authorization to repurchase an additional 3.1 million shares and we think very carefully about what we do with every dollar of cash flow that comes in.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We will go next to the line of Chip Dillon with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We will go next to the line of Chip Dillon with Credit Suisse.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good morning, Chip.
componenttext: Yes. Good morning, Chip.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. I just had a quick question, and I might have missed this, but as you look at your fourth quarter expectations, which I would imagine, are a little bit less than maybe what you were thinking ago few months ago. Would you say most of the lo
componenttext: Yes, thank you. I just had a quick question, and I might have missed this, but as you look at your fourth quarter expectations, which I would imagine, are a little bit less than maybe what you were thinking ago few months ago. Would you say most of the lower I guess outlook is tied to volumes in utilization, or is it tied to the raw material pressures and therefore it's just a matter of time before you pass those on?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the vast majority of that is related to the raw materials and as you know as we have talked before a lot of those are sometimes because of the way our contracts are structured about two-thirds of them have escalated, de-escalators and can take up
componenttext: I think the vast majority of that is related to the raw materials and as you know as we have talked before a lot of those are sometimes because of the way our contracts are structured about two-thirds of them have escalated, de-escalators and can take up to 90 days to pass those raw materials through. The other third, we take a look at it we can pass those through immediately on an order-to-order basis. So it takes us 60 to 90 days to pass that through, so I think that's a little bit of headwinds for us here in the fourth quarter.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I also like to clarify that our guidance throughout the year we have been raising our total year guidance throughout the year. So as we look at it it's, I don't think the fourth quarter expectations or guidance for fourth quarter is lower than we had expe
componenttext: I also like to clarify that our guidance throughout the year we have been raising our total year guidance throughout the year. So as we look at it it's, I don't think the fourth quarter expectations or guidance for fourth quarter is lower than we had expected earlier in the year. I think we had hopes in our July estimate had not, had some range and in there for very effectively with raw material costs and unfortunately as raw material costs going up in the lower half of the range we put out in July, but I think that our range for fourth quarter by itself is really very close to what we have expected for quite a while.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I totally understand, and just a quick follow-up. You mentioned you will get $30 million or I think, just clarify, are you going to be at a $30 million run rate at the end of this year with synergies, or is that what you get for this year? And then if you
componenttext: I totally understand, and just a quick follow-up. You mentioned you will get $30 million or I think, just clarify, are you going to be at a $30 million run rate at the end of this year with synergies, or is that what you get for this year? And then if you could tell us how we would expect those to phase in throughout 2011 to get to the $60 million. Is it kind of straight line, or is it lumpy?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chip. The answer is, yes, it's $30 million booked in 2010, which means that the run rate but by the end of this year will be higher than $30 million is we are going towards that target $60 million run rate by the end of 2011.Yes it's not a perfect s
componenttext: Sure, Chip. The answer is, yes, it's $30 million booked in 2010, which means that the run rate but by the end of this year will be higher than $30 million is we are going towards that target $60 million run rate by the end of 2011.Yes it's not a perfect straight line slope between where we are now and where we will be at the end of 2011. There is some lumpiness to it, but you will see us gradually grow from where we are now to the $60 million range a year from now.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: We have booked into our fourth quarter forecast, the price increases in raw materials that we have seen so far and we are predicting that pricing level will continue through the fourth quarter. That's how we break [ph] into our estimate here.

componenttext: The demand that we have going to the fourth quarter is strong. We feel good about it and you are right, our October is our big month and then you kind of go through the holiday seasons and that's what always makes the fourth quarter little slower than some of the others, but we feel very good with our volume in our backlogs going into the fourth quarter.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in terms of uses of cash, I guess piggybacking on the earlier question from Al. You enumerated the normal uses of cash; obviously the company has had a great dividend track record. You've made acquisitions, you want to invest in places where you
componenttext: Okay. And in terms of uses of cash, I guess piggybacking on the earlier question from Al. You enumerated the normal uses of cash; obviously the company has had a great dividend track record. You've made acquisitions, you want to invest in places where you're getting high margins and returns and, ultimately, you also buy back stock. As you sit here today, relative to maybe Bemis's priorities on cash flow a few years ago, do you think any one of those four or five are more important on a going forward basis than might have been the case previously?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well first of all, we have got a lot more debt now than we did before, right now we also have a lot of additional earnings but we think carefully about managing our debt levels. We are comfortable with where we are today, but we also want to make su
componenttext: Sure. Well first of all, we have got a lot more debt now than we did before, right now we also have a lot of additional earnings but we think carefully about managing our debt levels. We are comfortable with where we are today, but we also want to make sure we preserve flexibility for acquisitions that we expect will come. But there is really - it’s critically important that we think carefully about every dollar that comes in the house and whether we apply that to debt pay down, and right now we do not have any maturities that are coming quickly. The next bond of maturities is in the spring of 2012 and as we have said multiple times, we are not just going to sit on cash and so that's the reason why we look towards opportunistic share repurchases in the public market versus paying down commercial paper and at the same time preserving the flexibility we need to make acquisitions.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Good morning.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Good morning Chris.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you. The first is on Brazil. With all of the, we're hearing quite a bit of chatter out of folks down there that the packaging mix is evolving and changing so quickly, and with all of your, to more towards Flexible Packaging and things of
componenttext: Two questions for you. The first is on Brazil. With all of the, we're hearing quite a bit of chatter out of folks down there that the packaging mix is evolving and changing so quickly, and with all of your, to more towards Flexible Packaging and things of that nature. With your Dixie Toga business down there, is there an opportunity, or maybe you could talk about what the opportunity is over the next couple years, for that business to have 10%, 15%, 20% up volume levels to capture a lot of this conversion. So I guess the question is could you give us a little color on what's happening in Brazil and maybe where volume levels are now?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brazil is an exciting part of our growth strategy going forward. We were lucky enough to acquire Dixie Toga, which is the number one flexible packaging company in Latin America, so we are well positioned. It’s been the strategy all along to have that ki
componenttext: Brazil is an exciting part of our growth strategy going forward. We were lucky enough to acquire Dixie Toga, which is the number one flexible packaging company in Latin America, so we are well positioned. It’s been the strategy all along to have that kind of a base to work from and we always felt that as the population becomes more middle class that they are going to want the things that we all have here. Food safety, medical sterility are all important. We have invested in the shrink bag business, we have invested in putting assets into Brazil, that can grow in those key market areas and then we look forward to some very good growth not just in some of the more older established Dixie Toga product lines but also with our pharmaceutical business that we gained through the acquisition of Alcan, through the technologies that we could put into it in the packaging of protein also (inaudible) all of the convenience features that we have and we look to grow our medical device business now and then also. So we look for some exciting growth in Brazil especially in those key areas that we like to invest in.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay and then, my follow-up question had to do with the pressure sensitive business. And I apologize I jumped on the call a little late, if you already talked about this. But the trajectory as we've gone through the year has moved down a bit, as you look
componenttext: Okay and then, my follow-up question had to do with the pressure sensitive business. And I apologize I jumped on the call a little late, if you already talked about this. But the trajectory as we've gone through the year has moved down a bit, as you look at the EBIT contribution quarter by quarter. Is there anything unusual happening there that is driving that, or should we rebound back to the upper single-digit levels on a go forward basis?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it should rebound back to the upper single-digit levels on a go forward basis. We have had good volume growth this year compared to last year in our Pressure Sensitive business. We have had some cost pressures in Pressure Sensitive in raw material
componenttext: I think it should rebound back to the upper single-digit levels on a go forward basis. We have had good volume growth this year compared to last year in our Pressure Sensitive business. We have had some cost pressures in Pressure Sensitive in raw materials that we are working hard the pass through right now much like we have in the flexible packaging area.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The margins in that business are also very impacted by sales mix which could vary from one quarter to the other and I would say second quarter is generally a pretty strong margin quarter for Pressure Sensitive because of the strength of the sales in graph
componenttext: The margins in that business are also very impacted by sales mix which could vary from one quarter to the other and I would say second quarter is generally a pretty strong margin quarter for Pressure Sensitive because of the strength of the sales in graphic, and technical products in that particular part of the year.

componenttext: Thanks, hi guys. On pressure sensitive, we had heard from some of your trade contacts recently that you have also gone into some market with some pricing increases. componenttext: We have not only talked about those particular events on a conference call or in press releases. We do have very strong discipline throughout Bemis Company, flexible and Pressure Sensitive to the extent that we have raw material cost increases. We directly increase selling prices as soon as possible in areas where we can comparatively, so I think hopefully that addresses your question. We have had raw material costs increases associated with chemicals throughout both of our business segments over the last couple of months. So perhaps that's what you are referring to.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melanie. I think that addresses it. The other question I had, you had mentioned that the corporate spending run rate should be more or less $25 million, if I heard you correctly, over the next four quarters, or I believe into 2011 is what you ment
componenttext: Thanks, Melanie. I think that addresses it. The other question I had, you had mentioned that the corporate spending run rate should be more or less $25 million, if I heard you correctly, over the next four quarters, or I believe into 2011 is what you mentioned. Does that suggest that that's the appropriate run rate into the future, or that perhaps after 2011 there may be some ability for that level of spending to decline, and if that's the case, where perhaps could it get in to your perfect environment?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, that's the right expectation for the foreseeable future and there is a movement potentially between corporate expenses and once it’s allocated to our two reportable segments. But based upon the way you probably got your model set up right now, tha
componenttext: Sure, that's the right expectation for the foreseeable future and there is a movement potentially between corporate expenses and once it’s allocated to our two reportable segments. But based upon the way you probably got your model set up right now, that $25 million is a good assumption going forward.

componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks, just wanted to follow up on resin. Normally resin peaked in North America around the spring and has, and then fell, and then normally, you would have benefited from the lag on the way down as well. And it just doesn't seem like this time aroun
componenttext: Hi, thanks, just wanted to follow up on resin. Normally resin peaked in North America around the spring and has, and then fell, and then normally, you would have benefited from the lag on the way down as well. And it just doesn't seem like this time around you've seen that temporary lag benefit. And I'm wondering if you could just help us with what's happened there, if it’s things on the specialty resin side that's overwhelming that, if you could just help us think about that? Thanks.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Before I let Henry talk a little bit about resin costs, we in the second quarter your right that's the trajectory the resin costs for going for increasing in the first quarter and then started to decrease in May but those where really, the decreases where
componenttext: Before I let Henry talk a little bit about resin costs, we in the second quarter your right that's the trajectory the resin costs for going for increasing in the first quarter and then started to decrease in May but those where really, the decreases where coming primarily in the commodity resins and because they started decreasing half way through the second quarter, some of that benefit would have been received in the second quarter. So really muted the impact of the higher raw material costs going into the second quarter and then the benefit that you normally would have expected in the third quarter really it only benefitted the first parts of the third quarter I would say on the commodity side.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's a good explanation of what's going on. A lot of it just revolves around, what is the exact date the escalated/de-escalators passes through and we kind of cross ourselves here in the second and third quarter with falling and increasing with
componenttext: I think that's a good explanation of what's going on. A lot of it just revolves around, what is the exact date the escalated/de-escalators passes through and we kind of cross ourselves here in the second and third quarter with falling and increasing with various customers have different times that those escalated/de-escalators fire.

componenttext: Okay. And then just to follow up on an earlier question, with pricing catching up, is resin a headwind, than in the fourth quarter in your outlook, and do you expect by the end of the quarter your pricing should catch up?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is Dave Rose on for Tim Thein. I'm not sure if you talked about this before, but with the Alcan acquisition, from what I understand we didn't get a good look as to what sort of pensions you had to take over as part of that. So I'm wondering if yo
componenttext: Hi, this is Dave Rose on for Tim Thein. I'm not sure if you talked about this before, but with the Alcan acquisition, from what I understand we didn't get a good look as to what sort of pensions you had to take over as part of that. So I'm wondering if you could talk a little about where you expect pension contributions and/or expense to go, maybe not in fourth quarter but in 2011 and how you think that will impact your cash flow going forward?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, I can address that. In the Alcan acquisition we actually negotiated in asset purchase for the majority of the acquisition and so there were no additional pension or post-retiring medical liability that we took on with that. All those employees of Al
componenttext:
Sure, I can address that. In the Alcan acquisition we actually negotiated in asset purchase for the majority of the acquisition and so there were no additional pension or post-retiring medical liability that we took on with that. All those employees of Alcan came into Bemis Company as new employees of Bemis Company into our current benefit plans. As for as pension contributions going forward we had in the first quarter of this year, a small $15 million pension contribution which are focused to maintain roughly a 100% funded status in and both of our pension plans and that helps us get there for 2010.
Going into 2011 again, I would anticipate at this point there is no required contribution but depending on what the discount rate is at the end of the year and with the funded status ends up that we may decide given our cash flow projections to put some small amount into the pension plan in 2011. But again, no required contribution and pension expense grew 2009 to 2010. Given what the discount rates are looking like now, I would anticipate that the appropriate estimate an increased again for 2011, but we don't really know until we get to December 31 and see where the discount rates end up. So at this point, at least I would expect the pension expense to be about the same as where we are in 2010 which is roughly I think $20 million to $25 million and likely a little bit higher than that.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, with regards to deferred taxes, I know that's going to, was part of the acquisition purchase price. How are those going to flow into cash flow retirement, I know for the first couple quarters, that you've owned Alcan it's been fai
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, with regards to deferred taxes, I know that's going to, was part of the acquisition purchase price. How are those going to flow into cash flow retirement, I know for the first couple quarters, that you've owned Alcan it's been fairly flat within cash flow. Is that a line item that you should expect to see increase next year?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to the deferred tax, the cash flow is the deferred taxes or the cash flow with the tax benefit that we received in the Alcan acquisition because of the fact that we structured it as an asset purchase. Those cash, the cash benefit, the net pre
componenttext: With regards to the deferred tax, the cash flow is the deferred taxes or the cash flow with the tax benefit that we received in the Alcan acquisition because of the fact that we structured it as an asset purchase. Those cash, the cash benefit, the net present value is above $80 to $ 100 million and that's expected to roll into cash flow. Over the life of those assets and as you look at that the best way to model that is probably to say if you divide it evenly over seven years you wont to too far off and then, when your obviously there some that would go for substantially longer than that but really the bulk would be received over the next seven years. So not a dramatic cash flow improvement in any one year but we will get it in the near-term.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks.
componenttext: Okay, thanks.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just had one follow-up. I realized when I went through the Brazil questions we missed one part, and that was, could you talk a little bit about what the volume trajectory has been like the last couple quarters? And I know we talked about the opportunity
componenttext: I just had one follow-up. I realized when I went through the Brazil questions we missed one part, and that was, could you talk a little bit about what the volume trajectory has been like the last couple quarters? And I know we talked about the opportunity, but do you think that over the next two, three, four years there's an opportunity for that to be given all, ahead of all the conversion coming there, a double-digit type volume environment for you down in Brazil? Thanks.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start by saying what 2010 volumes have been like in. If you think about Brazil remember, their winter is in North America's summer and vice versa. What we saw was really strong volume double-digit nice volume in growth in Brazil year-over-year in t
componenttext: Let me start by saying what 2010 volumes have been like in. If you think about Brazil remember, their winter is in North America's summer and vice versa. What we saw was really strong volume double-digit nice volume in growth in Brazil year-over-year in the first half of 2010 and now in the third quarter volume was not as big driver not as strong as it was before but it's also, the latter part of winter in the third quarter in Brazil, so it's not the strongest time for their product. They are coming in now to their strong summer season as we enter into our fourth quarter and first quarter. Through the Huhtamaki acquisition we made last year, really focused on a lot of ice-cream packaging which is obviously a big summer time product and they have a lot of hotter drink mix and things like that. So in any event I think while the third quarter was slower year-over-year volume improvement, we have seen some really strong volume improvement year-to-date in 2010 and would expect that to continue going forward over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would expect that as Melanie described it good double digit growth in those quarters in the slow down and that trend that she is talking about in 2010 should continue into 2011 and 2012 for us.
componenttext: I would expect that as Melanie described it good double digit growth in those quarters in the slow down and that trend that she is talking about in 2010 should continue into 2011 and 2012 for us.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

componenttext: Yes, just one more follow-up on Brazil. Can Brazil pretty much fund its own growth?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brazil can fund its own growth, and Brazil has taken on debt in the past to make certain acquisitions by our joint venture partners in otherwise and we have repatriated cash from Brazil in years past. So it is a net cash flow generator and could cont
componenttext: Yes, Brazil can fund its own growth, and Brazil has taken on debt in the past to make certain acquisitions by our joint venture partners in otherwise and we have repatriated cash from Brazil in years past. So it is a net cash flow generator and could continue to fund its own, certainly its own CapEx.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, would you also, I think you picked up some assets in Argentina with the Food Americas deal, but would you see kind of moving that footprint into other countries in Latin America and if so what countries would be near the top of the list?
componenttext: Okay. And then, would you also, I think you picked up some assets in Argentina with the Food Americas deal, but would you see kind of moving that footprint into other countries in Latin America and if so what countries would be near the top of the list?

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We serve other countries in South America through our production facilities in Brazil and Argentina. We look at opportunities outside of those two countries and at this point we don't have any plans to put our production facilities in other countries, but
componenttext: We serve other countries in South America through our production facilities in Brazil and Argentina. We look at opportunities outside of those two countries and at this point we don't have any plans to put our production facilities in other countries, but it's something that we will continue to think about and monitor as our business down there grows.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Scott.
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Scott.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Hi, guys, last question. Henry, as you think about the Flexible Packaging business for you in your developed markets, your established markets, and you think about where you sit with your stable of new products and technologies. Do you think the g
componenttext: Thanks. Hi, guys, last question. Henry, as you think about the Flexible Packaging business for you in your developed markets, your established markets, and you think about where you sit with your stable of new products and technologies. Do you think the gap between you and your nearest competition in your key markets has expanded, or do you think that competition is to some degree catching up on you? And as you answer the question, could you give a few anecdotes or case studies that would validate your view on the world? Thanks. Have a great quarter.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, George. I think our new product is streamlined and the combination of some of the technologies and expertise that sided Alcan and that sit in Bemis together are going to drive new product developments. I think we are maintaining our lead and in
componenttext:
Thank you, George. I think our new product is streamlined and the combination of some of the technologies and expertise that sided Alcan and that sit in Bemis together are going to drive new product developments. I think we are maintaining our lead and in fact I think we kind of expanded our lead a little bit over our competition. However, I do think that the timeframe that, when you come out with a new product before your competition can copy it, is shrinking. So I think our lead and technology is growing but I think you hold that lead for a shorter period of time before people are able to come in and do a markup of that. So and then that's kind of how I see where we stand with our technology leads.
Some of the things you look at as an added doubt would be the - or the examples would be the microwaveable vegetables. We came out with those very quickly and on a number of years we have people that are trying to do some form of mark ups. We came out quickly with our stick pack programs using easy open features so that you could tear evenly across and pour that powder drink out. Others are coming in with copies of that, they can't quite meet with the technology that we have in the easy open feature. But we are following along with those products. Those are a couple of examples.

headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Henry.
componenttext: Thanks Henry.

componenttext: My last question, I promise. The CapEx guidance, it looks like you guys will be spending quite a bit more money in Q4 than you have on a run rate basis in the past three-quarters of the year. headline: Bemis Company, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nothing special in Q4, and we do think that the guidance we put out is the right level to assume but if we had to pick over or under it's more likely that we would fall shorter that for Q4 than that we will go over that for Q4.
componenttext: Nothing special in Q4, and we do think that the guidance we put out is the right level to assume but if we had to pick over or under it's more likely that we would fall shorter that for Q4 than that we will go over that for Q4.

componenttextpreview: Sure, couple of reasons. One, we have got more facilities now. Two, on our CapEx projects some of these are major asset purchases and the delivery schedule for equipment that we but for example, is not typically predictable and so as I said before, CapEx
componenttext: Sure, couple of reasons. One, we have got more facilities now. Two, on our CapEx projects some of these are major asset purchases and the delivery schedule for equipment that we but for example, is not typically predictable and so as I said before, CapEx doesn't fall neatly into three month period just because of what we are ordering and who is supplying the assets that we are purchasing.
